A stable Libya provides a buttress against foreign influence in the region.
Libya's stability is about more than Libya itself, as it has the potential to advance stability, transparency and accountability throughout the region.
39d93a1b1ebf86e738f722957c64696f:
Egypt participated in the Paris International Conference on Libya, reaffirming its commitment to rebuilding Libyan state institutions and achieving comprehensive national reconciliation.
President Al-Sisi emphasized the need to address the presence of mercenaries and foreign fighters in Libya to restore national sovereignty.
Egypt hosted a meeting between Libya's southern neighbors and the 5+5 Joint Military Committee to lay the groundwork for restoring security in southern Libya.
President Al-Sisi urged Libyan political forces to prioritize national interests and accept the results of the upcoming legislative and presidential elections on December 24.
Egypt expects improved conditions in Libya if the elections are successful and the balance of forces shifts towards those favoring peace.
Turkey's reluctance to remove mercenaries remains a concern, while Russia has expressed willingness to help remove forces linked to the Wagner Group under certain conditions.
Egypt hopes the Libyan elections will produce an authority capable of reunifying the military, tightening border control, and ending foreign military presence.
Egypt views the current interim phase as the most hopeful yet and trusts it will lead to lasting stability in Libya.
c1c9d3acd61e67defa6a156c15d738f6:
The African Union's (AU) Peace and Security Council (PSC) unanimously approved the Cairo Roadmap, an Egyptian document detailing how to reinforce the United Nations (UN) peacekeeping process.
The Cairo Roadmap is the outcome of a high-level regional conference held in the Egyptian capital in late 2018 and was ratified during a meeting of the African defence ministers held in Cairo in December 2019.
The Cairo Roadmap presents recommendations to support the UN chief's initiative for peacekeeping and to preserve the interests of African countries that contribute the most to UN peacekeeping forces, including Egypt.
The roadmap includes four main axes to enhance the performance of UN peacekeeping missions.
Egypt assumed the chairmanship of AU Peace and Security Council earlier this month.
61262971c172f210816f37d2d4cfd353:
Egypt’s Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry said Cairo will spare no effort in meeting the Libyan people’s aspiration for a secure and prosperous country free of any illegal foreign presence.
Egypt’s Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry stressed Cairo’s full commitment to achieving stability and development in Libya.
Egypt’s Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry stressed the need to hold presidential and parliamentary elections on time next month.
Egypt’s Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry stressed the need for all foreign forces to leave Libya as soon as possible.
Musa Al-Koni, vice president of the Libyan Presidential Council, expressed his appreciation for Egypt’s role in supporting stability in Libya.
f9f58b06a621b6a785acd73a5949dfd1:
Egypt and Qatar have been rapidly developing their rapprochement since the signing of the Al-Ula agreement in January.
EgyptAir has opened a new office in Doha, and the ambassadors of Qatar and Egypt have been holding meetings to promote investment.
Qatar is seeking to consolidate bilateral cooperation with Egypt, particularly in the financial and real estate sectors.
Qatari investment in Egypt continued during the four-year rift between the two countries, with an estimated $5 billion invested mainly in the real estate sector.
Qatar's sovereign wealth fund has an estimated $300 billion, and private Qatari investors are interested in the Egyptian market.
Egypt has taken measures to make the investment climate attractive, and the government plans to push the contribution of the private sector to economic growth to over 50% in the coming three years.
Egypt and Qatar have discussed cooperation in the field of maritime transport, as Egypt transforms itself into a hub for global trade and logistics.
Despite the thaw in relations, many in Egypt remain wary of Qatar because of its connections with the Muslim Brotherhood and the negative coverage Cairo receives from Doha-based Al-Jazeera.
Al-Jazeera's activities remain taboo in Egypt, and the channel is still blacklisted and its website remains blocked inside the country.
ee03c92c2b89c49ce3730c81e254066c:
Egypt's Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry emphasized the need for increased coordination among African countries to combat terrorism.
Shoukry highlighted the issue of porous borders and called for collective solutions to ensure a stable and prosperous Africa.
Shoukry urged cooperation between African countries and international institutions to address the growing links between terrorism financing and other financial crimes.
Egypt has implemented a comprehensive framework to combat terrorism financing, which has weakened terrorist activities within the country.
Egypt prioritizes cooperation with African nations in building capacities and sharing expertise in countering extremism.
Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi has ordered the reformation of religious discourse to align with moderate and true religious principles.
Egypt has expressed its commitment to supporting African states affected by terrorism as part of its moral and religious responsibility.
The Peace and Security Council (PSC) is the African Union's decision-making body responsible for conflict prevention and resolution.
Egypt holds membership in the PSC for 2020-2022.
Egypt has established the Sahel and Sahara Counterterrorism Centre in Cairo to coordinate counterterrorism efforts among CEN-SAD member states.
4301711cee057551dee79ea35ac76ec7:
Egypt's Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry met with EU Commissioner for Home Affairs Ylva Johansson in Cairo on Monday.
The two sides discussed ways to strengthen cooperation between Egypt and the European Union on migration.
Shoukry emphasized the importance of creating routes for legal immigration to Europe as a solution to illegal migration.
Johansson expressed appreciation for Egypt's efforts to combat illegal immigration.
d857ea943e91074fa33310bcfdd58170:
Egypt’s Universal Health Insurance System (UHIS) is a pioneering project and a model for the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region to follow, said French Ambassador to Egypt Marc Baréty.
France is eager to boost cooperation with Egypt across all fields and to support the country’s development plans; particularly in the transportation field and the UHIS.
President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi instructed the government to extend the UHIS’s umbrella to cover all governorates in 10 years instead of 15.
Egypt is aiming to achieve a sustainable economic growth rate that ranges between six and seven percent over the coming years under Egypt’s 2030 Vision.
The government plans to accelerate its initial public offering programme by listing more state-owned companies in the Egyptian Exchange over the coming months.
Egypt’s leadership is significantly keen on creating an investment climate in the country in which Egyptian and foreign private sector companies can play a role in the country’s mega development projects.
Egypt took pro-active containment measures to contain the socio-economic impacts of the pandemic, which required two percent of the country’s GDP to execute.
French investments in the Egyptian market amounted to around €5 billion in 2020.
There is a total of 165 French companies currently operating in Egypt that have around 38,000 employees.
Trade exchange between France and Egypt has reached €3 billion, which mainly includes food products, medicine, construction, telecommunications, environment, tourism, renewable energy, and automotive manufacturing.
85eeeb494a29c0a06f45d1a9acb12555:
Israel expects the upcoming presidential elections in Libya to pave the way for a new normalization agreement with Libya.
The two main Libyan presidential candidates, General Khalifa Haftar and Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, are both seeking to maintain contacts with Tel Aviv to gain approval of its ally, the United States.
Israel prefers Haftar as it looks forward to establish a foothold in the Mediterranean basin.
The two presidential candidates are ready to normalize ties with Tel Aviv, and the normalization constitutes an integral part of their undeclared election program.
Saddam, the son of Khalifa Haftar, visited Tel Aviv earlier this month and offered to enhance Tripoli-Tel Aviv ties, including granting Libya political and military aid, in return for reaching a normalization agreement.
Saif al-Islam Gaddafi has continued to maintain direct and indirect contacts with Tel Aviv after the ouster of his father in 2011 and asked for services in return for a promise of normalization.
The contacts between the candidates and Israel are backed by the United Arab Emirates, which is seeking to convince more Arab regimes to follow suit and normalize ties with Israel.
Israel seeks to “achieve more than one strategic interest” through reaching a normalization agreement with Libya and prefers that Khalifa Haftar win the election as he is an ally or “subordinate” to Israel’s allies.
Libya is of very great importance to Israel as its presence in Tripoli, through Haftar, would “guarantee the removal of the rival Turkish influence in the Mediterranean basin, not only on the security level, but also in terms of its economic security through expanding the circle of its allies, from Cyprus to Greece, and then to Egypt and Libya.”
Libya’s presidential elections are scheduled for December 24.
1acd780360ae085d9442ed397a78bb47:
Egypt's Minister of Water Resources Mohamed Abdel-Aty and head of the Palestinian Water Authority Mazen Ghoneim discussed ways to enhance cooperation and activate the MoU signed between the two countries in the field of water resources and irrigation.
The MoU between Egypt and Palestine aims to develop the Palestinian capabilities in water resources management and develop the skills of Palestinian technical cadres.
The 13th session of the Arab Ministerial Water Council, chaired by Lebanon, will be held on Thursday in Cairo.
The draft agenda of the session of the Arab Ministerial Water Council includes 24 items, namely the executive plan for the Arab water security strategy in the Arab region to address the challenges and future requirements of sustainable development (2010-2030).
The meeting will also discuss proposals to update the development following several comments suggested and adopted by Arab states before submitting them to the Economic and Social Council and the Arab Summit.
The meeting will include a presentation at the meeting of the mini-committee to discuss controversial items in the draft guiding principles for cooperation between Arab countries to exploit common water resources.
The meeting will also discuss an item on Arab preparations for the 9th World Water Forum 2022 in Dakar, Senegal.
The Council will be briefed on signing the MoU between the President of the current session, Qatar, and the Technical Secretariat of the Ninth Water Forum.
04a9e200b5f9ce052349e1effa8147fc:
The Ministerial Committee for the Development of Egyptian Exports to African Countries held its first meeting, chaired by the minister of Planning and Economic Development, Hala El-Saeed.
The meeting was attended by the ministers of Justice, Transport, Public Business Sector, Agriculture and Land Reclamation, Deputy Foreign Minister for African Affairs, Director of the Center for Information and Support for Decision Making at the Council of Ministers, economic advisor to the prime minister, as well as representatives from the Ministry of Industry and Commerce, the Egyptian Federation of Industries, Export Councils, the Central Bank, and several private banks, in addition to experts.
The committee aims to strengthen cooperation with African countries, increase trade exchange with the region and double the volume of exports until 2025.
The advisor to the minister of Planning, Mohamed Fathi Saqr, presented a detailed study on the current situation and proposed a plan to increase trade with African countries.
Participants agreed to study the proposed work plan and establish operational steps for each ministry and body represented in the committee in preparation for presentation to Prime Minister Mostafa Kamal Madbouly.
3d1229d29a794491397e41c5d40c9b01:
Egypt’s Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry called for an international multilateral system based on cooperation and awareness of common destiny to address challenges threatening humanity.
The 17th Manama Dialogue, an annual international diplomatic and security summit, was held in Bahrain from 19 to 21 November.
Attendees of the summit included US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, US Special Presidential Envoy for the Global Coalition to Defeat ISIS Brett McGurk, and UK National Security Adviser Stephen Lovegrove.
Shoukry emphasized the need to modernize international and regional multilateral action and bring new priorities to the international agenda, including emerging non-traditional challenges such as conflicts over natural resources, migration, and unemployment.
Shoukry called for giving space for justice among generations by listening to youth and understanding their priorities in international decision-making.
Shoukry stressed the need for international solidarity to face terrorism, climate change, the coronavirus pandemic, irregular migration, cyber and digital security, Artificial Intelligence, genetic modifications, space security, and other global challenges.
dcdb68d0f832c41b538a9bf6f1c285c7:
Libya's eastern military chief Khalifa Haftar registered to run for president in a December 24 election.
Haftar's announcement came two days after Seif Al Islam Qadhafi, son of former leader Muammar Qadhafi, declared his own candidacy.
Haftar vowed to defend "Libya's unity, independence, sovereignty" and called for "reconciliation and peace, construction and stability".
Haftar's candidacy marks the latest stage in his dramatic trajectory from exile in the United States to becoming one of the most controversial figures in Libya's 10-year conflict.
Libya's electoral process looks shaky just six weeks ahead of the vote, with disputes over who can stand and the legal basis for the polls.
Analysts have voiced scepticism over the chances of a free and fair vote, with some warning of the potential for intimidation or worse from Haftar loyalists.
The international community sees next month's election as a key step in restoring stability to Libya after a decade of conflict.
8c1dca8a4143f0b157c086f04fbc55c0:
Egypt will host the 21st summit of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) in its new administrative capital on Tuesday.
Twenty-one African countries will attend either in person or virtually, as well as COMESA’s secretary-general and a number of heads of African economic groups.
Egypt’s minister of trade and industry, Nevin Gamea, said the summit aims to encourage the use of digital-economy tools to facilitate business practices and enhance member states’ resilience against the economic repercussions of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Egypt is looking forward to making the most of Egypt’s second presidency of COMESA, 20 years after its first in 2001, especially in working to overcome obstacles to free trade between member states.
The summit is an excellent opportunity to introduce participants to Egypt’s new administrative capital.
The most important Egyptian exports to COMESA member states include plastics, salt, sulphur, lime, cement, ceramic products, machinery, electrical appliances, mill products, paper, sugar, soap, essential oils and perfumes.
a1b6c97d52beac7434e6833c9fef0528:
Egypt's presidency of the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA) aims to achieve regional integration by developing intra-regional trade and leveraging the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA).
Egypt will seek to follow up on a mechanism to review the trade policies of COMESA member states to ensure the effective implementation of customs privileges.
Egypt will strive to promote continental integration and highlight the progress made within the framework of the regional integration of COMESA, the East African Community, and the Southern African Development Community.
Egypt will also work on encouraging the countries that signed the AfCFTA agreement to start enforcing its terms.
Egypt has prepared an initiative for regional industrial integration with the aim of participating with member states and the general secretariat to draw up an executive plan to achieve this integration and increase productivity under the slogan ‘Made in COMESA.’
Egypt will also work on ramping up economic integration in the infrastructure sectors, especially transportation, energy, communications, and information technology.
Egypt is encouraging land-linkage projects between African countries, most notably the Cairo-Cape Town Project that is set to traverse through most of the countries of the COMESA.
Egypt is also looking to finalise a feasibility study to establish a naval route linking Lake Victoria and the Mediterranean through the Nile River.
Egypt will encourage the group’s general secretariat to cooperate with member states to prepare a list of clear investment opportunities to be presented to the business community and financing institutions.
Egypt urged enhancing the integration of the healthcare sectors of the COMESA's member states, especially amid the coronavirus pandemic.
Egypt will strive during its presidency of the COMESA to stimulate all initiatives that contribute to facilitating the business environment, especially digital transformation and financial inclusion initiatives.
Egyptian exports to COMESA countries increased by 32.4 percent in 2021, recording $2.3 billion during the first nine months of the year.
Egypt will increase the engagement of the Egyptian business community with the COMESA’s member states to benefit from the advantages offered by the economic bloc and will also develop inter-trade.
91f0844bde62652b6f2951cb61cd9dad:
Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi pledged to achieve Egypt's vision of deepening economic integration among regional countries and speed up economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.
Sisi stressed the vital role played by the regional economic group to achieve sustainable development for member states.
Sisi indicated that the progress made in continental economic integration has also been accompanied by many challenges.
The region is still suffering from the repercussions of the coronavirus pandemic and the recovery is slow.
The summit launched the COMESA medium-term Strategy 2021-2025, which came as evidence of a clear and thoughtful vision by all member states to enhance cooperation in all fields.
Sisi confirmed Egypt's full support and continued assistance to all the African peoples in their pursuit of achieving regional economic integration.
Sisi urged member states to increase awareness among the citizens of the COMESA region to benefit from the COVID-19 vaccines.
aaceaa69c9aa4a5917a29d507e9294ab:
Egypt has started early preparations to host the COP27 United Nations Climate Change Conference in 2022 in Sharm El-Sheikh.
Minister of Environment Yasmine Fouad held coordination meetings with several ministers to develop an action plan.
Finance Minister Mohamed Maait suggested organizing a climate finance day.
Minister of Planning Hala al-Saeed proposed opening a network of research centers for climate change across the country.
The 2022 event will be divided into various sessions to discuss the agenda of the previous conference, the initiatives taken by the host country and the side events to support these initiatives.
The events, on the sidelines of the COP27, will be held in coordination with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The meeting touched on the possibility of implementing a youth program to agree on ambassadors for climate change.
The ministers agreed on the importance of forming a working group in each ministry to follow up on the implementation of the tasks of the technical, logistical and political subcommittees.
Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly decided to form and chair a supreme committee of ministers of environment, finance, planning and international cooperation in preparation for the event.
a24aa18b67bae885ded55a1fa379a32a:
Abu Dhabi Crown Prince Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan held separate phone calls with Iraq Prime Minister and Egypt's President.
Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi discussed cooperation, joint work, regional and international issues, and agreed to boost fraternal relations and consolidate security and stability in the Arab region.
Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan and Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi explored means of boosting ties and advancing cooperation between the two nations, and discussed regional security and stability.
3ce7b44581aae9733e50156c283a6d5e:
Algeria's army chief of staff Said Chengriha started an official visit to Egypt on Sunday for talks with Egyptian military officials.
Chengriha was invited by Egyptian Defense Minister Mohamed Zaki to attend the EDEX 2021 defense exhibition in Egypt.
EDEX 2021 will display defense and military equipment of local Egyptian companies as well as international military equipment manufacturers.
f0743dbba0b763b8f98640a4cb84b52a:
Egypt is continuing efforts to develop its partnership with the EU and explore new vistas of cooperation.
Egypt's partnership with the EU is profound, varied and serves both sides.
Egypt is keen on taking part in all the activities of the Union for the Mediterranean (UfM).
Egypt is preparing to host the 27th climate change conference (COP 27).
Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry discussed a wide range of issues of mutual concern with his Finnish counterpart Pekka Haavisto.
Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry discussed bilateral relations and regional and international issues of mutual interest with his Slovenian counterpart Anže Logar.
Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry met with a number of European and Arab officials and top diplomats, including the European Commissioner for Neighbourhood and Enlargement Olivér Várhelyi and High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Josep Borrell.
ce31d5869751be52b038396e676b90d7:
UAE Minister of State for Defense Affairs Mohammed bin Ahmed Al Bowardi met with Egyptian Defense Minister General Mohamed Ahmed Zaki on Tuesday.
They discussed international and regional developments and ways to enhance defense and military cooperation.
Bowardi hailed the highly-organized exhibition, which is a major military forum in the Middle East.
Bowardi emphasized the deeply rooted and historic ties between the two fraternal countries.
Egyptian Chief of Staff Osama Askar met with his Saudi counterpart General Staff Fayyad bin Hamed al-Ruwaili, Chief of Staff of the Algerian People's National Army Said Chengriha, and Chief of Staff of the Qatari Armed Forces Salem bin Hamad bin Mohammed bin Aqeel al Nabit.
The officials discussed means to strengthen military and security fields, as well as future cooperation in various fields.
EDEX 2021 kicked off on Monday at the Egypt International Exhibition Center in New Cairo and continues until December 2.

91a2d582b0532e291f0a67e5d099f0ff:
Iran's aerospace commander of the country's Revolutionary Guards said Iran's drones have become "splinters in the eyes" of its enemies.
The US and Israel accuse Iran of using drones and missiles to attack American forces and Israeli-linked ships in the Gulf to destabilize the region.
Iran insists its military strategy is defensive, and has blasted Washington for tying talks on reviving the Iran nuclear deal to future negotiations on its missile program.
Brigadier General Amirali Hajizadeh said, "Our enemies say we should negotiate on missiles... and our drones have become splinters in their eyes."
Hajizadeh said, "If they insist on limiting the capabilities of our missiles and drones, it shows our strength."
Hajizadeh said, "We don't need to mention our strength because the enemy talks enough about Iran's missiles and defensive capabilities."
The US last month announced sanctions targeting Iran's drone program, saying the Guards had supplied them to its allies in the Middle East, including Lebanon's Hezbollah, Yemen's Huthis and the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas in the Gaza Strip.
Hajizadeh said Israeli "threats" against Iran, especially against its nuclear facilities, were statements meant for "internal consumption".
Hajizadeh said, "The Israelis can launch (an attack on Iran) but we will decide the outcome."
Iran warned Israel in October against "any military adventure" aimed at its nuclear program, after Israel said it reserves the right to use force against the Islamic republic.
e3676931e43a51feb868378f9a67f535:
A joint naval drill was conducted by Israel, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, and the United States in the Red Sea.
The drill was meant to send a "direct message" to Iran and its "power projection" in the region.
The exercise included training on the USS Portland and aimed to "enhance interoperability between participating forces' maritime interdiction teams".
The U.S. 5th Fleet, based in Bahrain, operates in the Arabian Gulf, Gulf of Oman, Red Sea and parts of the Indian Ocean.
Iran announced its own large-scale sea, land and air military drill in the Gulf of Oman, Sea of Oman, and northern Indian Ocean.
Iran's military exercise aims to display its military might and readiness to confront enemies.
Iran's Aerospace Force commander warned that any mistake made by Israel would expedite its destruction.
abe82540480724263f59b72ba9787227:
Israeli F-15 fighter jets escorted American B-1B bombers through the region for the second time in a month.
The joint flight of Israeli F-15 fighter jets and American B-1B bombers is a tacit threat to Iran.
The Israeli and American officials have increasingly threatened to act against Tehran’s nuclear program.
Iran has stalled its indirect negotiations with the United States in Vienna regarding a mutual return to the 2015 nuclear deal.
c676aaa8a36eef668fa16c55280a9a9c:
Naval forces of the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Israel, and the United States have held a joint maritime exercise in the Red Sea.
The five-day drills include training on the USS Portland vessel and will “enhance interoperability between participating forces’ maritime interdiction teams.”
An Israeli naval officer told reporters that the start of such military cooperation under US auspices could help counter Iran’s “power projection” in the region.
The US 5th Fleet is based in Bahrain and operates in the Persian Gulf, Sea of Oman, Red Sea and parts of the Indian Ocean.
Iran has repeatedly called on regional countries to rid the region of “extra-regional forces” in order to establish sustainable security through intra-regional cooperation.
The UAE and Bahrain were respectively the first and second Arab countries that normalized their ties with Israel last year under US-pushed agreements which were called the Abraham Accords.
Saudi Arabia is reportedly preparing its ultra-conservative population and “waiting for the right moment” to officially announce a normalization deal with Israel.
The Biden administration has promised to rejoin the Iran nuclear deal, officially called the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), and abandon Trump’s “maximum pressure” campaign against Tehran.
Talks on the Iran nuclear deal began in April but were halted after Iran’s presidential election in June.
Iran has recently announced that the talks, held in the Austrian capital Vienna, will resume on November 29.
Biden’s special envoy for Iran, Robert Malley, will “lead an interagency team to the United Arab Emirates, Israel, Saudi Arabia, and Bahrain from November 11-20.”

768256d2fe1a31ca988034a991b6881c:

The back-and-forth claims and threats mark another month of escalating tensions between the United States and Iran.
a1c7a932dec1f7ab5ba47bc564d8825a:
It is unlikely that Iranian missiles could sink a U.S. aircraft carrier.

Iran would likely launch every missile it could possibly throw at a carrier strike group, ideally scores or even hundreds of missiles.

Iran can be expected to continue to develop longer-range missiles with greater throw weights and improved accuracy.
0d971dcbda55e0a8d154d292cdbb8caf:
The Grumman F-14 Tomcat has been operated by only two nations: the United States and Iran.
Iran received eighty F-14 Tomcat jets in the early 1970s due to concerns that Iraq could outpace Iran's forces in a war.
After the Shah's regime fell in 1979, the Islamic Republic of Iran took control of seventy-nine F-14 Tomcat jets.
In the first six months of the Iran-Iraq War, the F-14 Tomcat reportedly racked up at least fifty air-to-air victories with only one aircraft damaged.
Iraqi pilots changed tactics to avoid engaging F-14 Tomcats, and Iranian pilots used the planes' sensors to coordinate other aircraft.
Iranian engineers made several improvements to the F-14 Tomcat, including adding bomb racks to transform them into ground-attack aircraft.
By the end of the Iran-Iraq War, the F-14 Tomcat had made at least two hundred kills, losing only eight to enemy action.
Due to U.S. sanctions, spare parts for the F-14 Tomcat were impossible to import, and the number of operational aircraft dwindled to around thirty in 1988.
Today, the number of operational F-14 Tomcat jets in Iran is estimated to have increased to forty, though their readiness varies.

aac57e521b3142c595a3541cd9083cb6:
Iran's missile forces are primarily composed of the Shahab-series of liquid-fueled short-range ballistic missiles (SRBMs).

The Sejjil is Iran's solid-fueled counterpart to the Shahab-3 liquid-fueled missile, with a range of 2,000 kilometers.

The raiding force could well consist of over 16,000 American Marines and sailors.

Iran’s Armed Forces hold routine military exercises throughout the year.
Iranian military experts and technicians have made great progress in developing and manufacturing a broad range of domestically-manufactured equipment.

6740cb38128b61468b550afe6b84ddcd:

Kornets are not "fire-and-forget" missiles and rely on a laser beam for guidance.

The drill was held in the Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz, and the coastal areas of the southern Iranian provinces of Hormuzgan, Bushehr, and Khuzestan.
The Islamic Revolution Guards Corps (IRGC) launched 16 ballistic missiles of different classes during the drill.
All the missiles hit the same target simultaneously.
IRGC's Chief Commander, Hossein Salami, said that the exercise conveyed a very clear message and a serious and real warning to Israeli officials.
34cc4e5e386567608e8e5c1c56625024:
Iran has been using its Fateh ballistic missiles to target adversaries in the Middle East.
The Fateh-110 missile has a range of 180 miles and can carry a payload of up to 1,433 pounds.
Iran has also developed an anti-ship version of the Fateh-110 called the Khalij Fars.
The Khalij Fars has a range of 190 to 220 miles and is designed to hit moving naval targets.
Iran has used Fateh missiles to strike targets in Syria, Iraq, and Saudi Arabia.
9ecb0b74fbb2dbdc56c6229551e1b2f7:
Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) destroyed a mockup of an Israeli nuclear installation during military drills.
The life-size target was obliterated by 16 ballistic missiles and five suicide drones.
The mock attack was part of the Great Prophet 17 military drills, a large-scale, five-day exercise in Iran that began on December 20.
The mockup of Israeli Dimona reactor, officially known as the Shimon Peres Negev Nuclear Research Center, was destroyed.
The Great Prophet 17 drills come amid heightened tensions between Iran and Israel, and in the wake of stalled talks on the 2015 nuclear deal.
Israel has consistently opposed the agreement and attempts to revive it, claiming that Tehran is seeking to produce nuclear weaponry, a charge that Iran has repeatedly denied.
Israel has reportedly been weighing a military option against Iran, considering a preemptive strike on its nuclear facilities regardless of the fate of the JCPOA.
Iran has warned Tel Aviv against such actions, with the commander-in-chief of the IRGC dismissing them as “Zionist empty threats,” and adding: “If the officials of this regime do a damn thing, we will cut off their hands.”
778c2c2fd7a15b06fed315e0375ee42f:
Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) fired sixteen surface-to-surface ballistic missiles during a five-day military drill as a warning to Israel.
The missiles fell into five categories, with ranges between 350 and 2,000 kilometers, or between 200 and 1,250 miles.
IRGC military leaders indicated that the exercises were intended mainly as a warning to Israel.
Maj. Gen. Hossein Salami, the leader of the IRGC, claimed that the exercise was intended as “a serious warning to Zionist regime officials.”
The military drill took place across Iran’s south and southwestern provinces and was dubbed “Payambar-e-Azam,” or “Great Prophet.”
The drill is being held at the same time that Iranian diplomats are pursuing nuclear discussions in Vienna, Austria, seeking to restore the 2015 “JCPOA” nuclear agreement.
Israel has made clear in recent months that it does not feel bound by diplomacy with Iran and will continue to pursue other means of constraining the Iranian nuclear program, no matter the outcome of the Vienna negotiations.
The United States has also indicated that it may pursue sabotage or other unspecified options if negotiations fail.
Iranian negotiators in Vienna have insisted that all sanctions from the Trump administration be dropped as a precondition to an agreement, but the Biden administration has rejected this demand.
The ongoing negotiations are scheduled to resume on Monday, December 27.
6610b77d103cf333781a9c6f73f9f5ab:
The United States expressed concern over Iran's new space launch, citing proliferation concerns.
The space launch vehicles used by Iran are similar to those used in ballistic missiles, including longer-range systems.
The launch violated UN Security Council Resolution 2231, which called on Iran not to carry out work on ballistic missiles with the potential to carry nuclear warheads.
Iran's Defense Ministry spokesman said the rocket used was an Iranian Simorgh (Phoenix) rocket and that the payload reached an altitude of 470 kilometers.
It is unclear whether any objects successfully entered Earth's orbit.
Iran's Tasnim news agency quoted the spokesman as saying the launch was a "space research mission."
European delegates to the nuclear talks warned that they are close to collapsing.
Iran's chief negotiator at the talks said some progress had been made on lifting sanctions.
Negotiations to restore the nuclear agreement resumed in late November and are due to resume on January 3.
27ec45d42068f2e791a00960c09ed2b6:
Iran launched a rocket with a satellite carrier bearing three research devices into space.
The launch comes amid ongoing negotiations in Vienna over Iran’s tattered nuclear deal.
The rocket used was a Simorgh, or “Phoenix,” rocket.
The three devices were sent up 470 kilometers (290 miles).
It is unclear if any of the objects entered orbit around the Earth.
Iran has suffered a series of setbacks in its space program in recent launches.
Iran’s paramilitary Revolutionary Guard runs its own parallel program that successfully put a satellite into orbit last year.
The US alleges such satellite launches defy a United Nations Security Council resolution calling on Iran to undertake no activity related to ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.
Iran maintains its satellite launches and rocket tests do not have a military component.
9f7f915af16c239c946f1df1bb7e4a53:
The U.S. is concerned about Iran’s development of space launch vehicles, saying there is a serious risk Tehran is building up its ballistic missile program and one could someday be used to carry a nuclear warhead.
The Iranian government claimed to have successfully launched a rocket carrying three satellite “research devices” into space.
Iran’s space program, which Tehran describes as for civilian purposes, violates a resolution in the United Nations Security Council that calls upon Iran not to undertake activity related to ballistic missiles “designed to be capable of delivering nuclear weapons, including launches using such ballistic missile technology.”
The U.S. continues to use all its nonproliferation tools to prevent the further advancement of Iran’s missile programs and urges other countries to take steps to address Iran’s missile development activity.
The Trump administration viewed Iran’s efforts to launch satellites into space as provocative military actions.
The Biden administration is engaging in an eighth round of indirect talks with Iran in Vienna over efforts to bring both parties back to the deal.
Iran, which claims its nuclear activities are for peaceful purposes, began violating the terms of the agreement in 2019 and has since far exceeded the constraints of the deal.
The U.S. and Iran have made “some modest progress” during the last round of talks, but it is too soon to say how substantive that progress is.
bb645bb5e4ca8fd248677776f715947f:
Tehran launched a satellite-carrying rocket into space with three devices onboard.
The satellite-carrying Simorgh rocket successfully launched three devices into space to a distance of 470 kilometers (292 miles) at a speed of 7,350 meters per second.
Iran's launch comes during ongoing talks in Vienna over the possibility of reinvigorating the Iran nuclear deal.
The decision to conduct the launch in the middle of already difficult negotiations is typical of the hardline government in Tehran.
The nuclear deal, officially known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), was first signed in 2015 by Iran and the US, as well as the EU, China and Russia.
Former US President Donald Trump unilaterally withdrew from the pact and reimposed harsh sanctions.
The current Biden administration is seeking to return to the deal, but efforts have so far been unfruitful, in part due to the more hardline government in Tehran.
bea5593d1f0fa762bd1fc842da6912b8:
France condemned Iran's launch of a rocket on Thursday, calling it a breach of UN Security Council resolutions.
Iran's defense ministry spokesman revealed that the rocket failed to put its three payloads into orbit due to insufficient speed.
The rocket was identified as a Simorgh, or "Phoenix," rocket that sent up the three devices 470 kilometers (290 miles).
The US State Department expressed concern about Iran's space launches, asserting they "pose a significant proliferation concern" regarding Tehran's ballistic missile program.
Israel's deputy chief of staff will travel to the US for talks with American counterparts, expected to focus on Iran.
Iran's civilian space program has suffered setbacks in recent years, including fatal fires and a launchpad rocket explosion.
Iran maintains its satellite launches and rocket tests do not have a military component.
Iranian nuclear negotiator Ali Bagheri Kani expressed hope for "more serious work to lift sanctions" when nuclear talks resume next week.
Iran has abandoned all limitations under the 2015 nuclear deal and ramped up uranium enrichment to 60% purity.
32b29c0a3e33624c821cd86946cab8e1:
Iran has announced a new space launch, putting its first military satellite into orbit in April 2020.
Western governments worry that satellite launch systems incorporate technologies interchangeable with those used in ballistic missiles capable of delivering a nuclear warhead.
Iran insists its space programme is for civilian and defence purposes only, and does not breach the nuclear deal or any other international agreement.
UN Security Council Resolution 2231 of 2015, endorsing the nuclear deal, imposed no blanket ban on Iranian rocket or missile launches.
Iran's state broadcaster aired footage of a rocket rising from a desert launchpad, but gave no details of its location.
Defence ministry spokesman Ahmad Hosseini said the Simorgh (Phoenix) satellite launcher carried three research cargoes into space.
Hosseini did not elaborate on the nature of the research, but he said the latest operation was a“preliminary launch” and that more would follow.
In February, Iran announced it had launched its most powerful solid fuel rocket to date, the Zoljanah, boasting that it can put a 220-kg payload into orbit.
The United States voiced concern about that launch, saying the test could boost Iran's ballistic missile technology.
Iran's declared new space launch comes amid talks underway in Vienna between the Islamic republic and world powers to restore the 2015 nuclear agreement.
Iran's chief negotiator Ali Bagheri said“relatively satisfactory progress” has been made in the talks.
Britain, China, France, Germany and Russia are taking part in the Vienna talks with Iran, while the United States is participating indirectly.
a83d894e747e1e54d8d7b609ea548435:
Iran’s Defense Ministry announced that the country’s domestically-built satellite carrier rocket, Simorgh (Phoenix), successfully launched three research devices in a space research mission.
The US State Department expressed concern with Iran’s development of space launch vehicles, claiming that such satellite launches would violate a UN Security Council resolution.
Iran’s Foreign Ministry spokesman Saeed Khatibzadeh condemned comments by the White House, stressing that scientific and research progress, including in the field of aerospace, is the Iranian nation’s inalienable right.
Khatibzadeh stated that no resolution prevents Iran from continuing its space program and the related experiments, including in the field of satellites-carriers, and that citing UNSC Resolution 2231 is purely fallacious and fundamentally untrue.
Khatibzadeh emphasized that Iran has the right to use peaceful technologies in the path of its scientific-research development according to international standards, and in so doing, it will not await the opinions of some countries that seek to impose their dictates.
7e710995044df5574e3e2ab5abd8b802:
The Revolutionary Guard Corps Navy (IRGC-N) has transformed an old target barge into a large-scale mock-up that loosely resembled the U.S. Navy's Nimitz-class aircraft carriers.
The IRGC-N reportedly launched a heavy warship named Abdollah Roudaki, capable of carrying helicopters, drones and missile launchers.
The Abdollah Roudaki is 150 meters or about 492 feet in length, and displaces some 400 tons.
The Abdollah Roudaki can reportedly carry out combat, logistical and intelligence-gathering missions.
The IRGC-N's role has largely been to patrol the waters of the Persian Gulf, but the Abdollah Roudaki could provide the IRGC-N with true blue-water naval capabilities.
91274bd242fdd055fa18f5b0aa8565f6:
In September 2003, U.S. authorities arrested Iranian Serzhik Avasappian in a sting operation for attempting to buy F-14 parts worth $800,000.
Tensions have escalated in the Persian Gulf region due to the U.S. withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement and alleged Iranian attacks on civilian ships.
The U.S. military has deployed aircraft carriers, bombers, and stealth fighters to the region to counter potential Iranian aggression.
The Iranian Air Force operates around 700 aircraft, including 24 F-14 Tomcats, which could be targeted by U.S. forces in the event of war.
Iran has struggled to acquire spare parts for its F-14s due to U.S. sanctions, leading to a black market trade in these components.
U.S. authorities have made numerous arrests and confiscations related to the illicit trade in F-14 parts, including the seizure of four ex-U.S. Navy F-14s in 2007.
Despite U.S. efforts, the underground trade in Tomcat parts continues, with shady companies scouring the planet for leftover components.
c79e151bb488f3c90fb9348d4706e2ce:
Iran's missile program has posed challenges to the U.S. regional military plan, according to U.S. political expert Andrew Korybko.
Iran's missile program has changed U.S. strategic military calculations by restoring an actual balance in the Middle East region.
The United States fears that Iran is upsetting the hitherto American-enforced regional balance of power.
Iran's Islamic Revolution Guard Corps (IRGC) staged a large-scale military drill along the southern coast of the country and fired 16 surface-to-surface ballistic missiles.
Iran launched a rocket into space carrying three research devices.
14ba27c1bb8cbf7e132576c8b9735b63:

Britain, China, France, Germany and Russia are taking part in the Vienna talks with Iran, while the United States is participating indirectly.
bfff437f2ed37b76d62925443b62a56f:
Mark Langfan, Chairman of Americans for a Safe Israel, believes Russian Kornet Anti-Tank Guided Missiles (ATGMs) are a serious threat to the USS Abraham Lincoln, a Nimitz-class aircraft carrier.
Langfan's analysis misrepresents the Kornet's capabilities and overlooks aspects of naval warfare.
In a deployment, the carrier would be backed up by destroyers and patrol ships, including Cyclone-class patrol ships with dual 25-millimeter autocannons and Griffin missiles optimized for use against small boats.
The carrier also has its own air wing to strike small ships before they enter engagement range.
The Kornet is not "fire-and-forget" and relies on a laser beam from the launching post for guidance.
Mounting a Kornet on a wooden-hulled small boat is impractical due to the unstabilized tripod firing post.
Carriers are armed with self-defense missiles and systems, such as the Phalanx CIWS or RIM-116 Rolling Airframe Missile, which can track and engage smaller missiles like the Kornet.
The Kornet's warhead is unlikely to do significant damage to an aircraft carrier due to the thin jet of molten metal created by its HEAT warhead and the dispersed nature of critical components on a ship.
The thermobaric version of the Kornet has limited penetrative capabilities and would likely not make its way through the hull.
09fcd79613fe49389b3c0d123bb67829:
Iran has unveiled a new fighter jet called the Kowsar, which is claimed to be "100% indigenously made."
The Kowsar appears identical to the F-5F Tiger II two-seater jet.
The Kowsar may merely be an avionics testbed for the Saeqeh fighter.
Iran is planning to build a combat-capable Kowsar advanced jet trainer, called the Kowsar-88.
The Kowsar-88 is influenced by the F-5 but is a different airplane and is much shorter.
Iran plans to acquire additional J85 engines on the black market or cannibalize the parts from older F-5 aircraft.
Iran is also planning to deploy fifty single-seat Saeqeh-1 fighters and fourteen two-seat Saeqeh-2 fighters.
Advanced jet trainers can perform counter-insurgency and strike missions far more cost-efficiently than a high-performance jet fighter.
Iran's fighter pilot training and sustainment of operational airframes are important in light of potential threats from the United States, Israel, and Saudi Arabia.
Iran's unveiling of the Kowsar illustrates the "casual dishonesty" of Tehran's propagandists.
7d9aadfab1b02e41e1e884da3f35193e:
Iran displayed three ballistic missiles at an outdoor prayer esplanade in central Tehran on Friday.
The missiles — known as Dezful, Qiam and Zolfaghar — have official ranges of up to 1,000 kilometers (620 miles) and are already-known models.
Diplomats from countries that remain in the 2015 nuclear deal — Britain, France, Germany, Russia and China — are working with Tehran to revive the accord.
American diplomats are present at the nuclear talks in Vienna but they are not in direct talks with Iranians.
The display came on the second anniversary of a ballistic missile attack on bases housing American troops in Iraq in retaliation for the US drone strike that killed top Iranian general Qassem Soleimani in Baghdad in 2020.
The Iranian military mistakenly shot down Ukraine International Airlines Flight PS752 with two surface-to-air missiles after the attacks, killing all 176 people on board.
An Iranian military court in November held a hearing for 10 people suspected of having a role in downing the Ukrainian airliner.
16927ed95a27c7745042be56f8c9f2d1:
Iran's military drills are deterring Israel's threats against Tehran, according to the spokesman for the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.

Iran displayed three ballistic missiles at an outdoor prayer esplanade in central Tehran, the same types as those used to strike United States bases in Iraq.
Diplomats from countries that remain in the 2015 nuclear deal are working with Tehran to revive the accord, but American diplomats are not in direct talks with Iranians.

9245c299a902cbaadd90d0b34cdd6503:
Iran displayed three ballistic missiles at an outdoor prayer esplanade in central Tehran on Friday.
The missiles — known as Dezful, Qiam and Zolfaghar — have official ranges of up to 1,000 kilometers (620 miles) and are already known models.
Diplomats from countries that remain in the 2015 nuclear deal are working with Tehran to revive the accord.

3ed59c7fb178c1e412e3ecbd7d710b00:
Iran has become a leading global missile producer, with the largest and most diverse arsenal in the Middle East, including thousands of ballistic missiles with a range of more than 2,000km.
Iran is seeking to capitalize on Chinese technology to develop projectiles that can circumvent missile defense systems.
Experts believe North Korea is now importing Iranian missile technology.
Iran is a few short months, or weeks, away from nuclear breakout capacity, with increasingly advanced centrifuges enriching uranium to 60 percent purity.
Iran’s increasing reliance on drones, cyberattacks and unconventional warfare aspires to give Tehran a decisive military advantage over its neighbors.
Iran has proved that it is using its ballistic missile program as a means to coerce or intimidate its neighbors.
Tehran’s military arsenals are shielded deep underground in massive complexes in its satellite states and in Iran itself.
Israeli military strikes and sophisticated sabotage operations have simply made Iran’s proliferation programs more resilient.
In the 15 years since Iran was referred to the UN Security Council for its uranium enrichment activities, it has developed into a ballistic superpower.
If diplomats and leaders in the Arab region and the wider world don’t rapidly get serious, Iran’s missile, nuclear and paramilitary programs soon won’t be an abstract matter of statistics and research data, but will be deployed in anger to rain death and destruction upon the region.
2ff9362757260c426874b93b228814bc:
Defense Minister Benny Gantz may soon travel to Ramallah to meet Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas.
The meeting would be Gantz's second with Abbas since the current government was sworn in in June.
The meeting would likely deal with proposals for security and economic cooperation aimed at helping the PA govern in the West Bank and weakening the rival Hamas terror group.
Shin Bet chief Ronen Bar told members of the high-level security cabinet that the PA is in a difficult economic and governmental situation, and that there is a fear of its collapse.
The past few weeks have seen a rise in Palestinian terror attacks, with four taking place in Jerusalem alone.
999e62fdff26e1e1bb6b02559a573d63:

The purpose of the meeting is to strengthen Abbas and the Palestinian Authority, so that Hamas will not be strengthened in Judea and Samaria.
Several proposals for security and economic cooperation that will assist the PA in its day-to-day operations will be presented.
Regional Cooperation Minister Issawi Frej will also join Gantz in his visit to Ramallah.

Following the meeting, Israel agreed to loan the PA NIS 500 million.
ed780cede10692207dc274c45409cb86:
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas suggested to the United States, Egypt, Jordan, and other parties that the negotiations with Israeli parties begin with “border demarcation.”

Abbas will inform Gantz that confidence-building measures and support for the Palestinian Authority (PA) are in no way a substitute for political negotiations.
Abbas will inform Gantz that the plan he launched at the UN would be implemented if the current Israeli government insisted on following a path away from political negotiations.
Abbas will meet Gantz next week, accompanied by the Israeli Regional Cooperation Minister Issawi Frej.
The meeting is also expected to address security and economic cooperation.
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said that his government strongly opposes the establishment of a Palestinian state.
Abbas is trying to push a political solution forward, and for that, he visited Russia, Jordan, Qatar, and other countries.
Abbas also requested meetings with Bennett and Foreign Minister Yair Lapid.
Bennett has refused to meet with Abbas so far, considering that it is useless in the current circumstances.
5a4ef7eb5ae5c9cef0b25ec80fc6048a:
The Palestinian Authority (PA) expressed support for Public Security Minister Omer Barlev's statement on "settler violence".
The PA called Barlev's statement an unprecedented "official recognition" of the violence of "settlers" against Palestinian Arabs.
Barlev came under fire on Monday over the comments, which he made following a meeting with US Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, Victoria Nuland.
Barlev said that the US official was "interested, among other things, in the settler violence and how to reduce tensions in the region and strengthen the Palestinian Authority."
Barlev wrote, "I told her that increasing the work permits for Palestinians in Israel, both from Judea and Samaria and Gaza, which we are already carrying out, is a key to reducing tensions, just like implementing the plan to establish a joint industrial zone on the outskirts of Gaza and more. American assistance for such projects can help a lot."
The remarks were heavily criticized by politicians from the right, including both members of the opposition as well as members of the coalition such as Interior Minister Ayelet Shaked.
Prime Minister Naftali Bennett tweeted following Barlev's comments, "The residents of Judea and Samaria have been suffering from violence and terrorism, every day, for decades. They are the defensive wall of us all and we must strengthen them and support them, in words and deeds."
Bennett later picked up the phone and held a clarification conversation with Barlev, in which he told him that "it is not right to generalize entire sectors in an offensive manner."
a07c19937150aaab59fee5868def8a0b:
Mansour Abbas, head of the first major Arab party to enter a government coalition, stated that Israel's status as a Jewish state is unchangeable.
Abbas advised the Arab community to adopt a pragmatic approach and work within the government to improve their status, rather than challenging the country's identity.
Abbas's Ra'am party is the first Arab Israeli party to join an Israeli coalition government in decades.

56ef94849dc88e8a3f68b532af19eeaf:

Palestinians in the cities of Lydd and Ramle and Yaffa endure terror at the hands of Zionist terror gangs.
Palestinians suffer from settler violence inflicted both by soldiers and by armed Zionist gangs who wear no uniform.
4c57c8aa78852ac2e18dd072de05a50c:

Palestinian factions are marginalised, with Hamas' acceptance of the two-state paradigm standing in contrast to its rhetoric of liberation.
The PLO's statement rightly reflects the Palestinian people's sentiment, but what of the politicians gambling away with Palestinians' lives?
15972d5b8eb7b5452f6503b928f4db7e:

Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas met with Israeli Defense Minister Benny Gantz in Israel on Tuesday.
It was the first time Abbas met with an Israeli official in Israel since 2010.
The two discussed "security and civil matters," including the importance of creating a political horizon and the tense field conditions due to the practices of settlers.
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said after the meeting in August that there weren't any ongoing peace talks with the Palestinians, "and there won't be one."
Israeli-Palestinian relations have substantially deteriorated in recent years, with several instances of violence being reported in the West Bank in recent weeks.
4e7c0187ce827cc1edc5d3243f0be206:
Benny Gantz approved a string of trust-building concessions following his meeting with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.
The concessions include the addition of hundreds of entry permits for Palestinian businessmen and vehicles, additional VIP permits for dozens of PA officials, and the advancement of tax payments to the authority worth NIS 100 million.
Gantz approved the status approval of some 6,000 Palestinian residents of the West Bank and 3,500 Gazans in the PA’s Population Registry, which is under Israeli control.
Gantz and Abbas reportedly also discussed the need to approve additional outlines that would benefit the Palestinians, including of "additional building programs" in the West Bank.
The meeting between Gantz and Abbas came amid growing unrest in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and a number of consequent attacks aimed against Israeli civilians, as well as against IDF troops and police officers.
The Defense Minister's Office added that the meeting and the concessions were part of an effort to "avoid a third intifada."
126c4732488d1a85c6f15d7d188c29b6:
Israel will implement a series of measures to prop up the indebted Palestinian Authority and ease Palestinians’ daily life.
Israel will provide the PA with a NIS 100 million loan ($32.2 million) on tax revenues Israel collects on Ramallah’s behalf.
Israel will legalize the status of 9,500 undocumented Palestinians and foreigners living in the West Bank and Gaza.
Dozens of senior Palestinian officials will also received prized “VIP” permits that allow them to freely cross through Israeli checkpoints.
Another 1,100 senior Palestinian businessmen will receive commercial passes.
Israel is considering lowering fees for purchasing fuel and a pilot program to allow shipping containers to enter the West Bank from Jordan via Allenby Bridge.
Prime Minister Naftali Bennett is opposed to renewed peace negotiations with the Palestinians and has refused to meet with Abbas.
Gantz has said he sees Abbas’s regime as the only alternative to an empowered Hamas in the West Bank.
Gantz and Abbas, in their Tuesday meeting, also discussed legalizing more Palestinian construction in the West Bank.
542722b2e71138715e6eeb76263f511c:
Israel's Defense Minister Benny Gantz approved measures to improve relations with the Palestinians after meeting with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas in Israel.
The measures include transferring tax payments to the Palestinian Authority, authorizing permits for Palestinian merchants and VIPs, and approving residency status for thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Israel collects taxes on behalf of the Palestinian Authority, and the tax transfers are a key source of funding for the Palestinians.
Israel has withheld funds over the Palestinian Authority's payment of stipends to families of those killed, wounded or imprisoned in the conflict.
Israel approved residency for some 9,500 Palestinians, as Israel controls the Palestinian population registry and its policies have left tens of thousands of Palestinians without legal status.
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett is opposed to Palestinian statehood and has shown no interest in reviving peace talks.
Recent months have seen a surge in violence by Israeli settlers against Palestinians in the West Bank and Palestinian attacks on Israelis in east Jerusalem and the West Bank.
Gantz's meeting with Abbas drew criticism from Israeli opposition lawmakers, including former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party.
The Palestinians seek an independent state that includes all of the West Bank, east Jerusalem and the Gaza Strip, areas Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.
00461b0adefd3221d4cd2cb93433a796:
Right-wing members of Israel’s coalition government criticized Defense Minister Benny Gantz for meeting with Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas.
Gantz hosted Abbas at his home in central Israel on Tuesday to discuss security and civilian topics.
Gantz told Abbas that he intended to continue advancing “confidence-building measures” in the economic and civilian sphere.
Gantz emphasized the parties’ shared interest in deepening security coordination, maintaining regional stability and preventing terror and violence.
Housing and Construction Minister Ze’ev Elkin said that Gantz hadn’t been given authority from the government to conduct political negotiations.
Elkin said that Gantz’s decision to host Abbas while the latter still supports terrorists demonstrates the defense minister’s “poor taste.”
Communications Minister Yoaz Hendel noted that Abbas still denies the Holocaust, and accused the Palestinian leader of playing “a very strange and double game.”
Hendel said that Israel has an interest in the Palestinian Authority being strong and stable in its field, but does not trust its people on security issues.
This was the second meeting between Gantz and Abbas.
d2ecce22314e217ad36b0c795b743544:
Israeli Defense Minister Benny Gantz met with Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas on Dec. 28 and offered a series of “confidence-building measures” to the Palestinians, including economic benefits, a loan, entry permits, and the legalization of undocumented Palestinians.
Gantz’s concessions to the Palestinians have been criticized by some Israelis, who question what confidence-building measures Israel received in return and why Israel is offering so many significant concessions to the Palestinians.
Efraim Inbar, president of the Jerusalem Institute for Strategy and Security, said that the meeting had “a façade of intimacy that is inappropriate” and that Abbas is “not a friend, but the enemy.”
Gantz’s office published a generic statement devoid of details, saying, “The defense minister emphasized the shared interest in strengthening security cooperation, preserving security stability, and preventing terrorism and violence.”
The details of the meeting were subsequently publicized, revealing the far-reaching concessions that Gantz had made to the Palestinians.
Gantz appears to be violating the 1994 Paris Protocol agreed to between Israel and the P.A. by making changes to the agreement without bringing any legislation to the Knesset for debate.
Abbas is personally leading a campaign to prosecute Gantz in the International Criminal Court for alleged war crimes.
The Likud released a statement calling Bennett’s government “an Israeli-Palestinian government that is returning Abbas and the Palestinians to the agenda… Concessions that will be dangerous to Israeli security are only a matter of time.”
The meeting was praised by the United States, which has been pushing to renew ties with the Palestinian Authority that had largely been severed under Trump.
Maurice Hirsch, head of legal strategies at Palestinian Media Watch, said that the aim of the meeting was ostensibly to prop up the P.A., but that the Palestinian people hate the P.A. so much that they would vote for Hamas in a heartbeat.
Hirsch said that the NIS 100 million loan for the Palestinians is “positively going to go to terrorists. It is outrageous.”
Hirsch also noted that Gantz is making agreements with the P.A. without any real oversight and without presenting any type of legislation.
Inbar said that Israel is actively supporting the P.A. because it is “afraid of the collapse of the P.A. that serves us well in the short term, sparing Israel the responsibility for managing the lives of the Palestinians.”
2fe86bdec8c876055fa9009148689955:
Former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu is ordered to return 30 gifts given to him during his 12-year term as premier.
Netanyahu's lawyers say many of the gifts were not returned because “some were broken and some were lost.”
Prime Minister’s Office legal adviser Shlomit Barnea Farago is expected to notify Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit, who will decide whether or not to probe the matter.
Netanyahu's lawyers say some of the gifts were found, others were lost or broken years ago, and others were taken by staff at the Prime Minister’s Office, during a major renovation of the office.
8385369e9144c497bd3e34545d63b126:
Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas warned Russian President Vladimir Putin that Israeli policies risk triggering an “explosion” in the West Bank.
Abbas cited Israeli settlements, home demolitions and “settler terrorism” as factors leading to anger in the West Bank.
Abbas told Putin that the continuation of these Israeli measures will lead to an explosion of the situation.
The US praised the economic measures announced by Israel to ease the economic situation of the Palestinian Authority and reduce tensions in the West Bank, but Abbas told Putin they were not enough.
Abbas said that economic and security steps are not a substitute for the political track.
According to the Israeli army’s annual report, 100 attacks were carried out in 2021 against Israelis in the West Bank, up from 60 a year earlier.
The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs recorded 410 attacks by Israeli settlers against Palestinians in the first 10 months of 2021, compared to 358 in the whole of 2020.
Abbas told Gantz that he would not support a return to violence in the West Bank, “even if a gun were held to my head.”
Abbas asked Gantz to allow greater freedom of action for Palestinian security forces in the West Bank, vowing to crack down on any violence toward Israel.
Gantz’s office announced several “confidence-building measures” following the meeting, including approving the inclusion of 6,000 West Bank residents and 3,500 Gaza residents to the PA’s resident registration on a humanitarian basis.
45240b9f6693bff27c4de35a45b47d71:
Palestinian Authority head Mahmoud Abbas has warned Russian President Vladimir Putin that Israeli raids and other acts of aggression have put the occupied West Bank on the brink of an “explosion.”
Abbas told Putin that Israeli settlements, land confiscation, home demolitions and "settler terrorism" are becoming a casus belli for a new revolt in the West Bank.
Abbas rejected “economic and security steps" offered by Israeli leaders, saying they are not "a substitute for the political track."
The Palestinian leadership will have to take “key decisions” at an important session of the Central Council of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) expected to be held in the coming months.
According to figures by the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, during the course of the first 10 months of 2021, Israeli settlers carried out 410 attacks against Palestinians, compared to 358 in the whole of 2020.
Since 1967, Israel has kept expanding settlements in the occupied territories of the West Bank and East al-Quds. Now more than 600,000 Israelis live in over 230 settlements, all of which are illegal under international law.
4ae54e758d9f4dbfb42cc7350251bb62:
Israel unveiled a package of "confidence-building measures" for the occupied West Bank after Defence Minister Benny Gantz hosted talks with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.
The measures include a $32 million advance payment to the PA in taxes collected on its behalf by Israel, the granting of 600 extra permits allowing Palestinian businessmen to cross into Israel, and the regularisation of 6,000 more Palestinians living in the occupied West Bank.
The talks also covered “the tense conditions on the ground due to the practices of settlers” as well as “many security, economic and humanitarian issues”.
Israel’s right-wing opposition Likud Party condemned the latest meeting, saying that “concessions dangerous for Israel’s security are only a matter of time”.

92d1248134d5a13d2ab2642e2c181fbb:
The Israeli-Palestinian conflict has continued with no significant changes on the ground.
The Trump-Netanyahu alliance has ended, with Trump expressing negative feelings towards Netanyahu.
The Israeli political scene has changed with a new coalition led by Naftali Bennett, who is pro-settler.

Palestinian civil society has become more active, connecting different parts of the Palestinian body politic.

Israeli settlers have been used to undermine Palestinian resistance and resilience, with attacks resembling pogroms.

b594ad05c628599853aeb9326753e6c4: Palestinian Authority (PA) chairman Mahmoud Abbas accused Israel of “hideous policies of ethnic cleansing and organized terrorism” in a speech marking the 57th anniversary of the launch of the first attack on Israel by his Fatah faction.
cc3e30fd6ce26bf00a49e231654aa0fa:
Defense Minister Benny Gantz defended his meeting with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, vowing to continue meeting with him.
Gantz hosted Abbas at his home in Rosh Ha’ayin last week, the first time the PA leader met with a senior Israeli official inside Israel since 2010.
The meeting was strongly criticized by right-wing opposition parties and some hawkish members of the ruling coalition.
Gantz said “the need to maintain Israel’s security” was the main focus of his meeting with Abbas, along with countering the Hamas terror group.
Gantz said he believed it was in the Palestinians’ interest “that calm create a healthy economy for them with a horizon for a better future.”
Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said he had given his “full approval” for last week’s meeting.
Gantz’s office announced several “confidence-building measures” following last week’s meeting, including approving the inclusion of 6,000 West Bank residents and 3,500 Gaza residents on a humanitarian basis in the PA’s resident registration; advancing the transfer of NIS 100 million ($32.2 million) in tax payments; and adding 600 BMC (businessman card) approvals for senior Palestinian businesspeople.
1ce34f12909e218adb8a75a7e9c69eac:
Foreign Minister Yair Lapid predicts that Israel will be accused of apartheid towards Palestinians by the United Nations in the coming year.

Palestinians are expected to increase pressure on the International Criminal Court to investigate Israel's conduct in the territories.
The UN commission investigating the May 2021 fighting between Israel and Gaza factions is expected to conclude that Israel is an apartheid state.
Israel must avoid appearing to refuse negotiations with Palestinians to counter the apartheid accusations.
Lapid believes that the Iran nuclear talks in Vienna will ultimately end with some sort of deal.
Israel's goal is to prevent sanctions being lifted on Iran and to minimize the damage of any agreement.
Israel is holding discussions to make access to money more difficult for Iran and to highlight issues missing from the 2015 deal, such as Iran's missile program and support of terrorism.
b8903a421bdc576026e93570be4c3f54:
Foreign Minister Yair Lapid said he would have no problem meeting with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas if the political conditions justified such talks.
Lapid stressed that such talks would not deal with a diplomatic solution between the Israelis and Palestinians, as the current government's policy of not holding final-status negotiations with the PA will remain in place when he becomes prime minister in August 2023.
Lapid indicated that part of his agreement with Prime Minister Naftali Bennett upon forming a government was that neither of them would hold peace negotiations with the Palestinians.
The focus of the government in its ongoing contacts with PA officials revolves around security cooperation, improving the daily lives of Palestinians, and strengthening the Palestinian economy.
Defense Minister Benny Gantz pushed back Monday against criticism of his recent meeting with Abbas, vowing to continue meeting with the PA leader.
Gantz hosted Abbas at his home in Rosh Ha’ayin last week, the first time the PA leader met with a senior Israeli official inside Israel since 2010.
Gantz's office announced several “confidence-building measures” following last week’s meeting, including approving the inclusion of 6,000 West Bank residents and 3,500 Gaza residents on a humanitarian basis in the PA’s resident registration; advancing the transfer of NIS 100 million ($32.2 million) in tax payments; and adding 600 BMC (businessman card) approvals for senior Palestinian businesspeople, as well as 500 permits for businesspeople, with such approvals to enter Israel with their vehicles, and dozens of VIP permits for PA senior officials.
910fc8ad8b16832453aed5e724f65697:
Palestine Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and Israeli Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence Benny Gantz met on 28 December 2021 to discuss security threats and violence.
The meeting was unique because it took place outside an official negotiating venue and did not focus on the "peace process" or "Abraham accords."
Abbas and Gantz are constrained by their political situations, with Gantz unable to make significant concessions due to his coalition and Abbas facing challenges from Hamas.
The meeting resulted in confidence-building measures such as security cooperation and residency rights for Palestinians in Jerusalem.
The meeting is part of a broader process involving the US-Palestinian Economic Dialogue, which aims to improve economic relations and support a two-state solution.
The Palestinian process aims to prevent further population loss and avoid extremism, while also rallying support for a peace process that addresses the one-state solution and racism in Israel.
defa405067804c3a468e1f198c6050ff:
Israeli Foreign Minister Yair Lapid called for a diplomatic dialogue with the Palestinians.
Lapid said the Diplomatic-Security Cabinet would soon convene to discuss a scenario in which the Palestinian Authority announced it was willing to start talks with Israel.
Lapid said that Israel should expect to see a significant increase in allegations from the Palestinians and their supporters that Israel was an apartheid state.
Israeli sports and cultural institutions would be the first to be impacted if the situation were to deteriorate.
The Foreign Ministry would focus a large part of its efforts on contending with such anti-Israel campaigns in the new year.
Foreign Ministry Director-General Alon Ushpiz said there is real danger an official U.N. body will determine Israel is an apartheid state.
fadf91829f62c802d8d6e097e5fd0ae8:
Israeli Defense Minister Benny Gantz met with Palestinian Authority leader Mahmoud Abbas at Gantz's home in Rosh Ha'ayin.
Gantz and Abbas discussed implementing economic and civilian measures, emphasizing the importance of deepening security coordination and preventing terror and violence.
Israel announced a series of "confidence-building measures" for the Palestinian Authority, including VAT, import-tax and excise-duty benefits, a NIS 100 million ($32.2 million) loan, more than 1,000 permits for Palestinian businessmen entering Israel by car, dozens of VIP permits for P.A. officials, and the legalization of the status of 9,500 undocumented Palestinians and foreign nationals living in Judea, Samaria and Gaza.
Israel's decision to provide these benefits to the Palestinian Authority is driven by the belief that it is in Israel's interest to keep the financially strapped P.A. from collapsing.
Abbas has made it clear that he would use any financial assistance from Israel to maintain his "well-oiled murder machine."
Abbas canceled the P.A. legislative elections slated for last May, claiming that Israel was unjustly forbidding eastern Jerusalem Arabs from casting ballots.
Abbas's speeches in Arabic and the messages conveyed through the media outlets and education system that he controls cite the nakba ("catastrophe") of Israel's establishment in 1948.
Abbas accused Israel of "hideous policies of ethnic cleansing and organized terrorism" at a celebratory event on Friday, just three days after extracting valuable promises from Gantz.
Gantz announced that "Only those who are responsible for sending soldiers into battle know how deep the commitment is to prevent it" in the aftermath of Abbas's visit to his house.
ca58a6f11ad5cf3647eb865d7f8f5915:
An Israeli security movement has called on Prime Minister Naftali Bennett to stop meetings with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas.
The movement said Abbas is a "supporter of terrorism, a Holocaust denier, and a corrupt dictator who hates his own people".

953566f25f51c6c8b7b5efee41219892:
Israel’s Foreign Minister Yair Lapid predicts an intensified campaign to label Israel an apartheid state in 2022.
Israel's population in the West Bank is at half a million and still growing, which is over 5% of Israel’s population.
Israel continues to build settlements on the West Bank, indicating its intention to keep it.
Israel’s anti-BDS law makes no distinction between boycott of Israel and boycott of the settlements, including the West Bank.
Israel insists on calling products made in Israeli settlements in the West Bank as “Made in Israel”.
Israel treats the West Bank as if it was part of Israel while avoiding the risks and pains associated with outright annexation.
If Israel does not change its policies in the West Bank, it is tacitly accepting that the West Bank is part of Israel, and therefore it is giving up on fighting the apartheid accusation.
