f45892e9d971fff6038722c82735ee31:
The Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS) in Israel has been using the term "Other" to designate citizens who identify as Jewish but are not considered Jewish by Jewish law (halakhah).
The CBS will end the use of the term "Other" and create a new category of "Extended Jewish Population" at the request of politician Yair Lapid.
The majority of this population is born to a Jewish father but not to a Jewish mother.
Many Israeli immigrants from the former Soviet Union who identify as Jewish are not considered fully Jewish upon arrival in Israel because they were born to Jewish fathers and non-Jewish mothers.
The majority of Jews today and the overwhelming majority of Jews in the future will not marry other Jews.
Israel will always keep its gates open for aliyah, and that means the country needs to face the reality of intermarriage and be more inclusive.
The steps being taken in Israel to be more inclusive may open a new discussion on this issue in the Diaspora.
0e02606fb4997c549703e4acc407690c:
Clashes between Israelis and Palestinians have occurred since the Zionist militias initiated the Nakba in 1948, resulting in the expulsion of over 750,000 Palestinians and the destruction of over 140 towns and villages.
The May 2021 confrontations between Palestinian resistance forces and Israel reignited debates on the legitimacy of each party and the feasibility of a lasting peace agreement.
Former US President Donald Trump's "deal of the century" in 2020, proposed without Palestinian involvement, aimed to continue annexations of Palestinian territories and legitimize Israel's actions since 1948.
Israel's Basic Law of the Nation-State, passed in 2018, legally established Israel as an exclusive state for Jews, aiming to Judaize Palestine and establish a state of Jewish supremacy.
Hamas's General Document of Principles and Policies, approved in 2017, declares the establishment of Israel as illegal and rejects recognition of Israel or its actions in Palestine.
Hamas advocates for the liberation of Palestine "from the river to the sea," including the establishment of a Palestinian state along the 1967 borders, with Jerusalem as its capital, and the return of refugees.
Hamas recognizes the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) as a reference for the Palestinian people and seeks to strengthen unity among Palestinian organizations.
Zionist leaders, including Naftali Bennett, deny Palestinian rights and oppose the establishment of a Palestinian state.
Palestinians distrust Zionists due to their non-compliance with agreements and continued expansion of occupation.
Advocates for Palestinian recognition of Israel as a precondition for peace agreements and normalization efforts are ineffective, as Israel has shown no willingness to end the occupation.
Accepting the occupier's reality would betray the principles of legitimate resistance and the aspirations of Palestinians for freedom and self-determination.
0fc08a4f878e1080be5691e10c759bc9:
Palestinians attribute Israel’s lack of action to Israel’s colonialism, while Israelis attribute the Palestinians’ lack of action to the Palestinians’ extremism.
Palestinians have been displaced from their homes and villages since 1947/48 and have been living in camps with limited prospects.
Palestinians have been promised their land back, but none of it has materialized.
Palestinians in Gaza are trapped between an oppressive regime and an Israeli blockade.
Palestinians in the West Bank are second-class non-citizens next to Israeli settlers.
Israelis have been fighting back against attempts to deny their right to self-determination and their right to live.
Israelis have made pragmatic choices, such as accepting the UN partition plan, living within the Green Line, and agreeing to two-state solutions.
Israelis have evacuated their troops from Gaza and forced their own settlers to leave.
Israelis have been at war since 1947, defeating three major attempts to destroy them, fighting several smaller wars, and enduring tens of thousands of terrorist attacks.
Israelis see no results from their efforts towards peace other than ever-increasing Palestinian extremism.
Israelis are scared mentally or physically by decades of fighting for their existence and sending their children to wars.
Palestinians see Israelis as racists and occupiers.
Israelis see Palestinians as antisemites and terrorists.
Both sides have thoroughly dehumanized the other and have given up on a peaceful solution.

Palestinians could disown extremist groups, recognize Israel as a Jewish state, and seek a negotiated solution.
Israelis could start taking steps towards leaving enough contiguous land in the West Bank for the Palestinians to build a viable state.
Due to the collective trauma suffered by each side, the extremists will likely continue pushing the conflict further and further away from peace and a reasonable compromise.
Outsiders should not demonize one side and glorify the other.
Outsiders should recognize that there are victims and trauma on both sides.
Outsiders should encourage each side to talk and listen to the other.
Israeli and Palestinian leaders should be seeking peace relentlessly and engage often in conversations with each other.
7f6a40fa25f1e1683dafeaecbebfc412:
Fatah movement reaffirmed its confidence in President Mahmoud Abbas in all his roles, including head of Fatah, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, and President of the Palestinian Authority.

Abbas has capitulated to Israel by deciding to stop the collection of evidence about Israel's war crimes to submit to the International Criminal Court.

dcfcc07f9709f65442b11b7948301f16:
Birthright, a program that offers free trips to Israel for American Jewish youth, is funded by philanthropists and the State of Israel.

50d44d47c1838c4d64c28f0821d6202e:
There is a consensus that there is no chance in the foreseeable future to reach a permanent peace agreement with the Palestinians.
The term "no partner for peace" has worn out due to repeatable use.
The voices that say the two-state solution is dead have gotten louder due to the growing unrest in the West Bank, the absence of a Palestinian leader who is willing to reach a peace deal, and the shift of Israeli society toward the right side of the political map.
Israeli expert on democracy, Prof. Matti Steinberg, said the current Israeli reality is pretty clear: it's either a two-state solution or deterioration into apartheid.
The dissipation of hate toward Israel by all Arabs states in the Middle East, thanks largely to the Abraham Accords, changed, without doubt, Israel's status in the Gulf region, and the new alliances with some Arab countries prove that.
The current trend appears to be calling for a temporary solution to the conflict by limiting the scope of Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories.
The two-state solution may have drifted away from the political agenda, but it's not gone.
Israel will never openly declare apartheid to be the case, but the international community might.
The difficulty of understanding the term "apartheid" is understandable. But it's just as important to understand that this is a process of a slow or fast deterioration into a startling reality.
The public and political discourse on the diplomatic solution to the conflict must be restored, at least as long as the Palestinian leadership is still committed to the Oslo Accords.
The Palestinian leadership is perceived as undemocratic, however, other Arab societies in the Middle East, including some of our friends, also have this kind of mindset.
The Biden administration can provide the sane and realistic discourse, with comfortable and improved circumstances for Israel.
416a4384a7eb907fbf9414ad958b8cd9:
Hamas adopted a new programme in May 2017, declaring itself a Palestinian national, Islamic, liberation and resistance movement that aims to liberate Palestine and confront the Zionist colonial project of the so-called "Jewish State".
Hamas defines Palestine as the land and home of the Palestinian people, extending from the Jordan River to the Mediterranean and from Ras Al-Naqurah to Umm Al-Rashrash.
Hamas does not recognise the right of the Jewish state over Palestine and believes that the occupation and expulsion of the Palestinian people does not nullify their right to the entirety of the land.
Hamas maintains that Israel is not a normal state, but an occupation of Jewish settlers brought from Europe, created during the mass expulsion and expropriation of the Palestinian people.
Hamas advocates that recognising Israel would mean legitimising all the Zionist claims and myths on which the creation of the State of Israel is based.
Hamas considers it absurd to use the recognition of Israel as a precondition for "peace agreements" or "normalisations" when Israel continues to oppress Palestinians and expand occupation.
The Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) recognised the "State of Israel" in 1988 and reiterated this recognition in the Oslo Accords in 1993, but Israel has never respected the terms of the agreements or recognised the Palestinian people's legitimate rights.
Hamas believes that negotiations with Israel have failed to bring back the rights of the Palestinians and that Israel does not abide by the agreements.
Hamas considers it unthinkable, immoral and unfair to expect Palestinians to capitulate to Israel's humiliating conditions.

Palestinian Authority (P.A.) official Hussein al-Sheikh met with Israeli Foreign Minister Yair Lapid to discuss political and bilateral issues.

P.A. President Mahmoud Abbas has repeatedly denied the legitimacy of Israel and referred to its establishment as a "catastrophe."

Fatah, the P.A.'s ruling party, has vowed retribution and declared war if Abu Hmeid dies.
2215cf1244e4c8098e09952349f04394:
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said he would not allow any talks leading to the establishment of a Palestinian state.
Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh said Bennett's statements prove Israel's extremism and hostility to peace negotiations.
Shtayyeh called on the United States and the European Union to intervene and halt Israel's plans in occupied East al-Quds.
Hamas political bureau member Ezzat Al-Rishq condemned Bennett's remarks, saying they are a slap to those who keep faith in negotiations with Israel.
Al-Rishq said the Palestinian state could be established through resistance and steadfastness.
More than 600,000 Israelis live in over 230 settlements built since the 1967 Israeli occupation of the West Bank and East al-Quds.
All the settlements are illegal under international law as they are built on occupied land.
d0623b618af6d4fb34d28a13295088aa:
Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammed Ishtaye condemned Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett's rejection of a Palestinian state as "incitement to violence" and proof of Israel's anti-peace stance.
Bennett stated that there will be no Oslo peace agreements and that he opposes the establishment of a Palestinian state.
Ishtaye called on the United States and the European Union to intervene to stop Israel's settlements in East Jerusalem.
Direct peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians have been suspended since 2014 due to disputes over Israeli settlements and the establishment of a Palestinian state on the 1967 borders.
73c5b496a48aa105c28871bb740d177e:
Nir Hefetz, a former confidant of Benjamin Netanyahu, testified that Netanyahu actively pushed for the establishment of Israel Hayom to blunt Israel’s biggest-selling newspaper, Yedioth Ahronoth, which Netanyahu considered hostile to him.
Hefetz told the court that Netanyahu helped enlist the late Jewish-American casino magnate Sheldon Adelson to set up Israel Hayom.
Hefetz alleged that Netanyahu threatened Yedioth Ahronoth publisher Arnon Mozes by saying that he had “personal information” about him.
Hefetz said there was no economic logic in founding Israel Hayom and that “it was likely established for an ideological reason.”
Hefetz argued that Yedioth had no clear agenda beyond maintaining as large a readership as possible.
Netanyahu faces charges of fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and in Case 2000, and charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in Case 4000.
41a5f6b659d53bfb3ed7116dfa16ffaf:
Nir Hefetz, a former close confidant of Benjamin Netanyahu, ended his testimony in the corruption trial against the ex-prime minister after more than five weeks and 17 hearings.
Hefetz is the state’s key witness in the trial against Netanyahu, who faces charges in three separate graft cases.
In Case 4000, the most serious against the former premier, Netanyahu is alleged to have worked to illicitly and lucratively benefit the business interests of controlling shareholder of the Bezeq media company Shaul Elovitch in exchange for positive coverage on the Walla news site owned by Elovitch.
In Case 2000, Netanyahu is accused of attempting to make a deal with Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper publisher Arnon Mozes for softer coverage of him in exchange for legislation to curb the reach of rival daily Israel Hayom.
Hefetz said a years-long high-profile battle between the newspapers, which included frequent public mudslinging by Israel Hayom against Yedioth Ahronoth, was “actually only about Netanyahu, about his continued leadership.”
Hefetz told the court that the former prime minister had actively pushed for the establishment of the free tabloid in order to blunt Yedioth, which he considered hostile to him.
Hefetz alleged Netanyahu threatened Mozes by saying that he had “personal information” about him.
Netanyahu denies all allegations against him, and says the charges were fabricated by a biased police force and state prosecution service, overseen by a weak attorney general, in league with political opponents and the media.
cc24d30175e5c04d855b89a5ec1f0e76:
Former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been ordered to return 30 gifts given to him during his 12-year term as premier, as they rightfully belong to the State of Israel.
Netanyahu's lawyers said they could not return the gifts because “some were broken and some were lost.”
Prime Minister’s Office legal adviser Shlomit Barnea Farago was apparently not convinced by the lawyer’s explanations, and she is expected to notify Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit, who will then decide whether or not to probe the matter.
A good governance group pressed Mandelblit to open a probe into the whereabouts of the gifts.
The Netanyahu family moved out of the Prime Minister’s Residence in Jerusalem on July 10, almost a month after Naftali Bennett succeeded him.
Among the items not yet returned are two gilded eagles Netanyahu got from then-United States president Barak Obama; a copy of the Bible with the first commentary by Rashi, given by Russian President Vladimir Putin; and a framed copy of documents then-US president Donald Trump signed ordering the transfer of the US Embassy to Jerusalem.
88005800338d56fc9503071071ec761d:
Benjamin Netanyahu is in talks with Yedioth Books to release a new book.
The book would include autobiographical details and would likely be published in English for an overseas audience.
Netanyahu has previously published books through Yedioth Books, but a book he wrote while serving as finance minister was shelved upon his return to the Prime Minister's Office.
Netanyahu never returned the advance for the shelved book, which was estimated to be worth NIS 140,000 ($45,000).
Netanyahu is also considering publishing the new book independently or releasing the previously shelved book through Yedioth.
08ecfba642eb4a90dd99205bf09d5346:
Judge rejected Benjamin Netanyahu's request to delay the hearing of his defamation lawsuit against Ehud Olmert.
Netanyahu's family filed a defamation lawsuit against Olmert for calling the then-prime minister, his wife Sara, and eldest son Yair “mentally ill” in interviews.
The lawsuit seeks NIS 837,000 (some $257,000) in damages for Olmert’s “obsessive efforts to harm their good name in public, out of jealously and deep frustration.”
Olmert said that “what is irreparable is the mental illness of the prime minister, his wife, and his son,” referring to Yair Netanyahu.
Olmert argued in his defense that his opinion reflects the atmosphere in parts of the public, and also that the words he used were not slander.
a97d04d61dc81015dec737d4c735575d:
Former Israeli Prime Ministers Benjamin Netanyahu and Ehud Olmert refused a settlement offer by a court in a defamation lawsuit brought by the Netanyahu family against Olmert.
Netanyahu demanded 837,000 shekels ($269,000) in damages following comments Olmert made in two Israeli media interviews last year that Netanyahu, his wife and son were mentally ill.
The settlement was offered during a hearing session, during which the judge suggested that Olmert state that his comments about the family's mental health were "only an opinion rather than a fact."
Netanyahu was accompanied by his wife Sara and their son Yair during the session.
a44c7acb803cdb2c6bab10ebec6f2ba4:
Opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu and prosecutors discussed a potential plea deal in his graft trial.
The secret talks broke down due to Netanyahu’s refusal to admit moral turpitude or accept a prison sentence.
Netanyahu believed that Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit would be interested in ending his term with a “clean sheet” and that the short timeframe before his retirement could bring to bear the pressure needed for a deal to be brokered.
Mandelblit ruled out extending his tenure despite the lack of a replacement.
The discussions between representatives of both sides were held under strict secrecy and went on for a number of weeks.
Mandelblit required a full admission of guilt and moral turpitude, as well as a suspended sentence with a substantial fine.
Netanyahu was not willing to entertain an admission of moral turpitude, and the talks quickly ended.
Netanyahu faces charges in three separate graft cases: fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and in Case 2000, and charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in Case 4000.
Netanyahu denies all allegations against him and says the charges were fabricated by a biased police force and state prosecution service, overseen by a weak attorney general, in league with political opponents and the media.
de19698dc6ccd26cb8642c7550d1794f:
Prosecutors are reportedly furious over reports that former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been holding secret talks with the attorney general over a plea deal in his corruption trial.
A plea deal that removes Netanyahu from the political sphere could cause the speedy collapse of the current governing coalition.
Netanyahu is on trial in three separate graft cases, after being indicted in 2019 for fraud, breach of trust and bribery.
Prosecutors will only agree to a deal that includes an admission of moral turpitude and community service for Netanyahu.
If his actions are found to have carried moral turpitude, a guilty plea would bar Netanyahu from public service for seven years.
The secret talks were reportedly initiated by Netanyahu’s attorney Boaz Ben Zur.
State prosecutors made clear that there would be no compromise on the conviction of moral turpitude.
Netanyahu is reportedly consulting with aides about moving forward with a deal.
Reports have indicated that Mandelblit may be eager to wrap things up before his term ends at the end of the month.
Netanyahu faces charges in three separate graft cases: fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and in Case 2000, and charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in Case 4000.
The details of the plea agreement that have already been agreed to would include dropping the bribery charge in Case 4000, as well as the entire Case 2000, and seeing Netanyahu admit to fraud and breach of trust in both Cases 4000 and 1000.
The sides have reportedly agreed that Netanyahu will not see prison time, and would be sentenced to three to six months of community service.
If Netanyahu’s political career is effectively over, many observers believe it would spell the end of the current government coalition.
89614c316513ff0de2d1f36e1be94b8d:
Top state prosecution officials were not aware of the negotiations for a plea deal with Benjamin Netanyahu until yesterday.
Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit held the talks secretly and only notified top figures tied to the case yesterday.
Some officials in the prosecution do not want to agree to close Case 2000 against Netanyahu.
Prosecutors will only agree to a deal that includes an admission of moral turpitude and community service for Netanyahu.
Netanyahu started considering a plea deal after receiving a legal assessment that the testimony of key state’s witness Nir Hefetz’s recent testimony was effective for the prosecution’s case.
Netanyahu may not be interested in a plea deal at all, and may simply be trying to depict the cases publicly as weak.
Courts are not a rubber stamp for plea bargains, and could feasibly reject one even if the sides agree to it.
If a deal is signed, it will present “an immediate danger to the stability of the coalition.”
e3681bd2a8d26b92e22c363fd5d046ae:
The Israeli government will vote on Sunday on the establishment of a state commission of inquiry into the "submarine affair," a deal between Israel and a German shipbuilder for naval vessels that has already resulted in multiple indictments.
Foreign Minister and Alternate Prime Minister Yair Lapid and Defense Minister Benny Gantz announced the upcoming vote on Friday.
A report on Channel 12 news cast doubt on their assertion, saying Prime Minister Naftali Bennett does not plan to bring the matter to a vote yet.
Gantz said that “the formation of a commission of inquiry is a necessary step to safeguard Israel’s security.”
Lapid added: “The submarine affair is the most serious case of defense corruption in Israeli history, and we must leave no stone unturned to reach the truth.”
The scandal, known as the “submarine affair,” or Case 3000, involves allegations of a massive bribery scheme in Israel’s multi-billion-shekel purchase of naval vessels from German shipbuilder Thyssenkrupp.
Several of those involved in the agreement have been indicted over the affair, including close confidants of former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
The scandal also involved the sale of two Dolphin-class submarines and two anti-submarine warships by Germany to Egypt, allegedly approved by Netanyahu without consulting or notifying then-defense minister Moshe Ya’alon and then-IDF chief of staff Gantz.
Gantz, now defense minister, submitted a formal request for a government inquiry back in October.
The probe also has the support of Finance Minister Avigdor Liberman.
Gantz’s proposal called for NIS 9 million ($2.85 million) to be budgeted for the commission of inquiry, with NIS 7 million ($2.22 million) coming from his Defense Ministry and NIS 2 million ($630,000) from the Justice Ministry.
ff277df1680377a2d72fb4103c1a1aff:
Former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu attempted to reach a plea deal in his three criminal cases two years ago, but the proposal was vetoed by his wife Sara.
The plea deal discussed between Netanyahu's attorney and Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit in 2020 was similar to the one currently being negotiated: removing bribery charges and admitting to fraud and breach of trust in exchange for community service and a "moral turpitude" conviction.
Sara Netanyahu rejected the 2020 plea deal proposal.
Netanyahu is currently on trial in three separate graft cases, including fraud, breach of trust, and bribery.
Secret negotiations for a plea deal were initiated by Netanyahu's attorney Boaz Ben Zur.
Prosecutors insist on a conviction of moral turpitude and community service for Netanyahu.
Netanyahu is reportedly trying to avoid the moral turpitude designation to maintain his political career.
The sides are at odds over when Netanyahu would resign from the Knesset, which would determine who decides on the moral turpitude charge.
A plea deal could lead to the collapse of the current governing coalition.
Netanyahu is reportedly consulting with aides about moving forward with a plea deal.
Netanyahu's consideration of a plea deal follows damaging testimony from state's witness Nir Hefetz and concerns about upcoming testimony from Shlomo Filber.
Top state prosecution officials were unaware of the plea deal negotiations until Wednesday.
Netanyahu faces charges in three separate graft cases: fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and Case 2000, and bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in Case 4000.
The plea deal would reportedly include dropping the bribery charge in Case 4000 and Case 2000, and Netanyahu admitting to fraud and breach of trust in Cases 4000 and 1000.
Netanyahu would not face prison time and would receive a sentence of three to six months of community service under the plea deal.
1a764bdc26c277a93547e5210de1f6ca:
Former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu wrote a book in the early 2000s titled “The Israeli Leopard” that was never published.
Excerpts from the book were published on Friday by the Haaretz newspaper, revealing Netanyahu's views on corruption, bloated governments, and the dangers of over-concentration of centralized power.
Netanyahu, now leader of the opposition, is currently on trial in three corruption cases, including fraud, breach of trust, and bribery.
In the book, Netanyahu compared corruption to "a cancer that grows in the darkness" and argued that it "distorts competition, hurts citizens’ morale, and discourages them."
Netanyahu also criticized the concentration of power in Israel, stating that "for years immense financial power has been concentrated in the government, the labor federation and the parties."
The book also contains advice on maintaining a small government, which Netanyahu himself quickly jettisoned on becoming prime minister again.
Netanyahu is reportedly trying to negotiate a plea deal with Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit, which would include dropping the bribery charge in Case 4000 and the entire Case 2000.
The main sticking point in the plea deal negotiations is that prosecutors will only agree to a deal that includes an admission of moral turpitude, which would see Netanyahu barred from office for seven years.
a7bfb3dcba900dcd685dadf1dd3da27c:
Former Supreme Court president Aharon Barak acknowledged that opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu had asked him to speak with Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit about the possibility of reaching a plea deal in the former premier’s graft trial.
Barak said that in recent months, senior figures in Netanyahu’s Likud party asked him to initiate talks with Mandelblit.
Barak stressed that any plea deal must include a clause that Netanyahu will be convicted of “moral turpitude” — a legal designation which would bar him from public office for seven years.
According to multiple television reports over the weekend citing unnamed sources, talks on a potential plea deal in the former prime minister’s criminal trial have made significant progress, and the state prosecution believes the ex-Israeli leader will sign such a deal within days.
Netanyahu, he insists, must first accept as a basic condition the framework of the deal: that he will be convicted of fraud and breach of trust; that he will remain an MK until the court determines his punishment and sentences him to 3-6 months in jail that will be commuted to community service; and that he will agree that his actions will be designated as carrying “moral turpitude” — barring him from public service for seven years.
3f712196693076141723a7e858f35066:
Former Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu is negotiating a plea bargain to end his corruption trial.
Netanyahu is discussing a deal with the regime's attorney general Avichai Mandelblit to plead guilty to reduced charges and have his jail term commuted to community service.
Netanyahu was indicted in November 2019 in at least three cases of alleged bribery, fraud, and breach of trust.
The prosecution has assembled more than 300 witnesses to back its allegations.
Netanyahu has been accused of offering regulatory favors for media executives worth about $500 million in return for securing positive press coverage.
Netanyahu has also been charged with receiving expensive jewelry, cigars, and champagne as gifts from a Hollywood producer and an Australian billionaire.
Netanyahu has denied all accusations and mocked the size of the witness list.
Talks with Mandelblit have snagged over Netanyahu's demand to be spared a conviction carrying a "moral turpitude" clause, which would force him to quit politics for years.
Netanyahu has vowed to unseat his successor Naftali Bennett.
83ad20d563bf8bc8686869770ab2a11f:
Former Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu is negotiating a plea bargain to end his corruption trial.
Netanyahu is discussing a deal with Attorney-General Avichai Mandelblit under which he would plead guilty to reduced charges and have any resulting jail term commuted to community service.
The talks have hit a bump over Netanyahu's demand to be spared a conviction carrying a "moral turpitude" clause, which under Israeli law would force him to quit politics for years.
Netanyahu is entangled in four political scandals: Case 1000, Case 2000, Case 3000, and Case 4000.
The State Attorney's Office declined to comment on the plea bargain negotiations.
A lawyer for Netanyahu did not immediately reply to a request for a comment.
Netanyahu has vowed to unseat his successor, Naftali Bennett.
With his legal troubles behind him, Netanyahu might in theory be able to muster a broad new rightist coalition.
If Netanyahu were barred from politics, right-wing members of Bennett's coalition could opt to form a new government with a Likud party under new leadership.
The idea of a plea bargain was promoted by a former Supreme Court president, Aharon Barak.
A spokesperson for Netanyahu's conservative Likud party said he did not know about any such negotiations.
84b815ab4c10c777212d735b911fd470:
A cabinet vote on establishing a state commission of inquiry into the “submarine affair” has been delayed by at least a week.
Defense Minister Benny Gantz and Foreign Minister Yair Lapid announced on Friday that the vote would occur on Sunday.
The vote has been delayed due to the government’s ongoing negotiations to purchase submarines from Germany.
The submarine affair involves allegations of a massive bribery scheme in Israel’s purchase of naval vessels from German shipbuilder Thyssenkrupp.
Several of those involved in the agreement have been indicted over the affair, including close confidants of former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Gantz and Lapid have both promised to establish a formal government investigation of the submarine affair.
Gantz submitted a formal request for a government inquiry back in October.
The probe also has the support of Finance Minister Avigdor Liberman.
Netanyahu has not been charged with wrongdoing in the incident and the attorney general has said he is not a suspect.
Netanyahu is currently on trial on three unrelated and separate corruption charges.
Netanyahu has been linked to the submarine affair, and his associates have been indicted over their role.
cc3db026449f02f295d4dfeccb29a2a8:
Opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu has agreed to Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit’s demand that a plea deal in his criminal trial include a clause banning him from public office for seven years.
Netanyahu has not yet informed Mandelblit of his decision, as he is not sure the attorney general is prepared for a plea deal.
Netanyahu’s spokesman released a statement that quoted his lawyers saying the former prime minister “has not announced he agrees to moral turpitude.”
Netanyahu himself appeared to downplay rumors that he had decided to sign a plea deal.
Netanyahu is on trial for fraud and breach of trust in three separate cases, and bribery in one of them.
The reports followed a meeting Netanyahu and his family held Sunday with his lawyers to decide whether to accept a plea deal.
Netanyahu’s wife Sara expressed reservations over accepting a plea deal.
Deputy State Attorney Liat Ben-Ari, the lead prosecutor in Netanyahu’s case, has cooled toward a potential deal.
State Prosecutor Amit Aisman backs an agreement while Mandelblit has become less enthusiastic about a deal.
If the terms of a deal are too lenient, the court may end up refusing to accept it, and if the charges are too severe, the court may demand a harsher sentence than the sides agree to.
It remains unclear if a deal can be reached before Mandelblit’s term ends.
Netanyahu thanked supporters who donated money as part of a crowdfunding effort to help cover the costs of his defense.
Foreign Minister Yair Lapid pushed back against recent reports that a potential plea deal for Netanyahu could bring down the coalition that was formed to oust the longtime premier.
Netanyahu is on trial in three separate graft cases: for fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and in Case 2000, and for bribery, fraud and breach of trust in Case 4000.
According to reports in recent days, the details of a plea agreement that have already been agreed would include dropping the most serious charge against him, for bribery Case 4000, as well as the entire Case 2000, and seeing Netanyahu admit to fraud and breach of trust in both Cases 4000 and 1000.
Netanyahu denies all allegations against him, and says the charges were fabricated by a biased police force and state prosecution service, overseen by a weak attorney general, in league with political opponents and the leftist media.
6d6463cde18492304d28b7a7b5734bca:
Opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu has instructed his lawyers to press ahead with talks with Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit on a plea deal in his criminal corruption trial.
Netanyahu and his family met Sunday with his lawyers to decide whether to accept a plea deal.
Netanyahu's lawyers would approach Mandelblit on Monday with a view to moving forward as soon as possible with the deal.
The Netanyahu family is concerned about public opposition to the deal.
The prospects of a deal being sealed before Mandelblit’s term ends at the end of January are low.
State prosecutors also cast doubt on the prospect of wrapping up a plea agreement before Mandelblit leaves office.
Netanyahu is on trial in three separate graft cases: for fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and in Case 2000, and for bribery, fraud and breach of trust in Case 4000.
57de548bca9d67b281744780de68a997:
Israeli Cabinet minister Omer Barlev dismissed claims that police used NSO Group spyware to surveil protesters.
Hebrew-language business paper alleged that the Israel Police used NSO Group spyware to hack the phones of protest leaders, municipal leaders and other citizens without proper oversight.
The police denied the report's findings and said they operate according to the law.
NSO Group said it does not identify its clients.
Israel's justice minister, Gideon Sa'ar, said there was an “unbridgeable gap” between the newspaper report and the police's statements.
The attorney general is also investigating the claims raised in the article.
Lawmakers called for formal parliamentary investigations into the matter.
A state ombudsman said his office would look into the allegations of unauthorized digital surveillance by the police for an upcoming report.
Tehilla Shwartz Altshuler, a digital privacy expert at the Israel Democracy Institute think-tank, said that if the police are found to have hacked citizens’ phones, it violates their basic rights to privacy.
22ad7ac4405a49b941927f3a3f219c19:
Former Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is negotiating a plea deal with prosecutors in his ongoing corruption cases.
The plea deal could bar Netanyahu from politics for several years.
Netanyahu would confess to "moral turpitude" in a series of corruption cases.
A moral turpitude conviction would see Netanyahu banned from Israeli politics for at least seven years.
Netanyahu is currently the leader of Israel's opposition.
In 2020, Netanyahu became the country's first sitting prime minister to be indicted for bribery and inappropriate political gifts.
Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit is retiring at the end of January.
Hundreds of protesters gathered outside of Mandelblit's house on Saturday, urging him to dismiss a plea deal and convict Netanyahu on all accounts.
Netanyahu's potential plea deal could rattle the Israeli parliament's coalition.
2a890eb030c2ee5738f2387d2a77ba08:
A plea bargain is an agreement between a defendant and the prosecution in which the defendant confesses to certain offenses in exchange for a reduced penalty.
Plea bargains save time and resources for the courts and prosecution, reduce the duration of a delay of justice, and limit the potential risk to both parties.
Plea bargains can spare victims a difficult and traumatic experience, and the defendant's confession constitutes taking responsibility for the action.
Plea bargains may deal a blow to justice by failing to reflect the full severity of the offense and harming future deterrence.
Plea bargains can lead to false confessions and undermine public confidence in the courts and prosecution.
In a public case, a plea bargain deprives the public of its right to know whether a crime was committed and what exactly took place.
Moral turpitude is a severe moral defect characterizing the person who committed a crime under the specific circumstances of its commission.
A person convicted of a crime with moral turpitude may be disqualified from holding public office.
If Netanyahu is convicted of offenses of moral turpitude, he will be expelled from the Knesset and will not be able to run for office for seven years.
The Attorney General's signature on a plea bargain agreement would bind his successor.
If the charges are revised as part of a plea bargain, the indictments against the other defendants must also be amended to coincide with the agreed-upon facts.
Negotiations for a plea bargain are not supposed to have any impact on the continuation of the criminal trial.
The court can decline to accept a plea bargain agreement, especially if the proposed sentence is unreasonably lighter than appropriate.
The High Court of Justice can intervene in a plea bargain if it finds a substantive flaw, but its review power is limited.
33805a99547e4b4a4d6b9174088bc1ce:
Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit initially offered former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu a plea deal that was more lenient than the one currently being discussed.
The initial plea deal would have required Netanyahu to step away from public life for two years, with the charges being significantly lowered in two of the cases against him and dismissed in the third.
Mandelblit backed away from the initial plea deal due to pressure from key figures in the prosecution.
The current plea deal being discussed would require Netanyahu to admit to fraud and breach of trust in cases 1000 and 4000, accept the designation of moral turpitude, be sentenced to seven to nine months of community service, and admit to instructing former Communications Ministry director Shlomo Filber to provide benefits to the controlling shareholder of the Bezeq media company, Shaul Elovitch.
Netanyahu and his lawyers are wary of accepting the terms of the current plea deal unless or until they are certain Mandelblit will finalize the deal.
Both Channel 12 and 13 said that it was likely a deal would eventually be reached, noting that politicians in both camps were already gearing up for the post-Netanyahu era.
84921631db9a0c380dc240bee4c81e50: Attorney General Avichai Mendelblit believes that Benjamin Netanyahu's trial will end with a sentence that puts him behind bars if a plea bargain isn’t signed.
Mendelblit insists that he did not promote a deal to enable Netanyahu to avoid prison because of his popularity.
fed6fe8ce8d421cf2d182aa104456cd5:
Public Security Minister Omer Bar-Lev denied reports that the Israel Police are using Pegasus software to collect information on civilians without criminal charges.
The Israeli business daily Calcalist reported that the police are using the military-grade spyware to collect intelligence and create dossiers as part of early stage investigations.
Police Commissioner Kobi Shabtai said that the force will keep using its "technological tools," in response to the reports.
Attorney General Avichai Mendelblit announced that he intended to set up a team to investigate the claims.
Shabtai said that the attorney general who looked into the matter, remarked in his letter that no basis had been found for the claims in the reports, and that the police had acted according to the law.
472baa28af86799624334c764792db56:
The Israeli government has approved the establishment of a commission of inquiry into the "submarine affair," which involves allegations of bribery in the purchase of German ships six years ago.
The graft scandal, known as "Case 3000," revolves around a possible conflict of interest and bribery in the $2 billion purchase of naval vessels from Germany's Thyssenkrupp.
Former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was questioned but not named as a suspect in the scandal.
Twenty-six ministers voted for the establishment of a state investigation, while Prime Minister Naftali Bennett abstained, expressing solidarity with Interior Minister Ayelet Shaked, who opposes an investigation into the previous government.
Defense Minister Benny Gantz initiated the proposal for an inquiry committee in October 2020 following leaks alleging Netanyahu's involvement.
The deal to procure the submarines was signed in 2016 and involved Netanyahu personally.
Case 3000 allegedly involved Israeli officials advocating for the purchase of submarines and patrol boats from Thyssenkrupp in return for kickbacks.
Netanyahu is also accused of approving Thyssenkrupp's sale of submarines and anti-submarine warships to Egypt.
Former Prime Minister Ehud Barak called the matter "the most serious corruption scandal in Israel's history."
Last week, Israel signed an agreement with Germany to purchase three submarines from Thyssenkrupp for three billion euros ($3.4 billion) to replace older ships.
7301f9c49ee3af9536f52d98e05b2788:
Aryeh Deri, Israel's former interior minister, has resigned from the Knesset after reaching a plea deal in a tax fraud case.
Deri admitted to minor tax offenses and paid a 180,000-shekel ($57,000) fine to avoid prison time.
Deri remains the leader of the Shas party, Israel's third-largest Knesset party.
Benjamin Netanyahu is negotiating a possible plea bargain to end his corruption trial and avoid prison time.
Netanyahu has denied all accusations and mocked the size of the witness list.
Talks with the attorney general have snagged over Netanyahu's demand to be spared a conviction carrying a "moral turpitude" clause.
81c556f66c800d62dc38a9bd6fcd943c:
Opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu publicly declared that he has not agreed to acknowledge “moral turpitude” as part of a potential plea bargain that would end his corruption trial.
Netanyahu vowed to remain the leader of his Likud party and of the right-wing political camp, and to eventually return to power and lead the country.
Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit informed Netanyahu’s attorneys that negotiations on a deal would have to wait until a new attorney general takes office.
Netanyahu had reportedly been hoping to seal a deal with Mandelblit, believing that the latter wanted to end his six-year term with a clean slate.
Deputy State Attorney Shlomo Lamberger said that it would be “inconceivable” for a plea deal not to include a clause of “moral turpitude.”
Foreign Minister Yair Lapid said that Netanyahu’s video was “proof” of the need to pass a law he previously initiated as head of the opposition, which would bar anyone convicted of moral turpitude from serving as prime minister, minister, Knesset member or mayor.
Netanyahu is on trial in three separate graft cases: for fraud and breach of trust in Case 1000 and in Case 2000, and for bribery, fraud and breach of trust in Case 4000.
Under the reported potential deal, the bribery charge in Case 4000 would have been dropped, and Case 2000 closed altogether.
Netanyahu denies all allegations against him, and claims the charges were fabricated by a biased police force and state prosecution service, overseen by a weak attorney general, in league with political opponents and the leftist media.
49f0f2b44a859e8230b926be9faf67ca:
Ministers have conducted at least 46 flights and trips abroad in the seven months since the government’s establishment, at a cost of NIS 10-16 million ($3-5 million).
Defense Minister Benny Gantz, Foreign Minister Yair Lapid and Prime Minister Naftali Bennett are the most frequent fliers.
Bennett has made six official trips abroad since coming into office in June, including visits to the United States, Egypt, Russia, Scotland, and the UAE.
The total cost of Bennett's six visits came to NIS 5,740,017 ($1,806,235), not including lodging, security and other expenses.
Lapid has taken eight "important policy trips" since taking office, costing NIS 3 million ($944,102).
Gantz has made five trips as defense minister, but did not provide any cost details.
Seven ministers have not traveled anywhere since the government was formed.
0097741b3105b330ca3292ad795993b1:
Former Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is reportedly negotiating a plea deal with prosecutors in his ongoing corruption cases.
The plea deal could bar Netanyahu from politics for several years.
The plea deal could further reshape Israel’s political landscape.
caca9df31917e7058c787aa3b69a1e2e:
Israeli cabinet ministers bid farewell to Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit, who will end six years in office on Monday night.
Mandelblit criticized former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is currently on trial for corruption, for attacking the rule of law.
Mandelblit faced accusations from both the left and right during his tenure, but was praised by cabinet members for his work in defending Israel on the international stage and indicting Netanyahu.
Justice Minister Gideon Sa’ar said that Mandelblit had withstood "an open, long, continuous and unstoppable attack for about two years, by the government itself and led by the [former] prime minister."
Far-right Religious Zionism MK Itamar Ben-Gvir welcomed the end of Mandelblit’s term, saying the attorney general had left “scorched earth behind him.”
Netanyahu did not immediately post any remark about the cabinet session on his social media channels.
Mandelblit officially ends his term on Tuesday, but so far no replacement for him has been selected.
c86235798ba3ee82351bf2ad679a6a15:
Israel police used spyware to access data in the phone of an individual involved in the trial of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
The hack was discovered by the Justice Ministry during its review of the police's use of the spyware.
The police claimed that the investigators never received the data, which was gathered against the police's procedures.
Attorney Jacques Chen, representing Shaul and Iris Elovich, who stand accused of bribing Netanyahu in Case 4000, said "If it's true, this is a serious crime, yet another expression of the loss of all restraint in the investigation against the Elovich couple, of which we have been warning for years."
Attorney General Avichai Mendelblit announced the appointment of an inquiry team into reports the force targeted activists and other Israelis with NSO's Pegasus.
Israel Police later admitted misusing of spyware by the force.
In January, news site Calcalist published a report alleging that the police used the Pegasus spyware on Israelis without court authorization since 2013.
The Pegasus spyware allows its operators to remotely access mobile phones infected with the software.
dd23ba4e641321a8c0d746c871f4719e:
The alleged draining of the contents of a key witness's phone by police in the trial against Benjamin Netanyahu may delay the legal proceedings.
The Jerusalem District Court will likely decide on Monday whether to halt Netanyahu's trial until police and prosecutors can clarify the extent to which phone hacking was used in the cases against him.
Police, without the necessary approval from a judge, used spyware to drain all the data from the phone of Shlomo Filber, a former director-general of the Communications Ministry and longtime confidant of Netanyahu who is a key state’s witness in Case 4000.
Attorneys for Netanyahu and other defendants in the case have demanded to know exactly what data was obtained, what use was made of it, and whether others involved in the trial were also targeted.
Prosecutors have responded that they are examining the matter.
Channel 12 reported Thursday night that Filber’s phone was accessed in 2017, and had the entirety of its content drained using unnamed spyware.
Police brass reportedly told justice officials that the data was downloaded accidentally and was never given to investigators in the Netanyahu cases.
Likud’s faction chair Yariv Levin termed the revelations “a giant Watergate affair, here in Israel” and called for the Netanyahu trial to be shut down.
Netanyahu is on trial in three cases, having been indicted for fraud and breach of trust in cases 1000 and 2000, and for bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in Case 4000.
b991d5f013dfdd44ab7d33ab2b630cd4:
The Jerusalem District Court may halt Benjamin Netanyahu’s trial on Monday to clarify the extent of phone hacking in the cases against him.
Police accessed data from the phone of Shlomo Filber, a state’s witness in Case 4000, without approval in 2017.
Police brass have reportedly told justice officials that the data was downloaded accidentally and was never given to investigators in the Netanyahu cases.
Netanyahu’s attorneys have demanded to know the extent of the spyware use, what use was made of the materials, and where the materials were kept.
Prosecutors are examining the matter.
Filber is set to begin his testimony in about two weeks, but it could be delayed until all material relating to him is given to the defense and the court.
If it turns out that phones of other witnesses were accessed, this could have even greater repercussions for the trial.
In Israel, unlike the US, evidence obtained illegally is not necessarily inadmissible in court.
Netanyahu called the revelations an “earthquake.”
Likud’s faction chair Yariv Levin termed them “a giant Watergate affair, here in Israel.”
62301cb43a5f095ad005062e9b68a0e4:
Boaz Bismuth is stepping down as editor-in-chief of Israel Hayom, opening the bidding to the right-wing leadership.
Israel Hayom was placed at the disposal of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu by Bismuth, turning Netanyahu into the editor-in-chief in practice.
Netanyahu dictated the newspaper’s headlines and policy, and for years conducted his relationships with his rivals on the pages of the newspaper.
Miriam Adelson, the paper’s controlling shareholder, is seeking a somewhat different policy – right-wing but less Bibi-ist.
Israel Hayom played a decisive role in Netanyahu’s criminal entanglements.
Netanyahu’s desperate need for friendly, ego-stroking media drove him crazy and destroyed all his supposed precautions.
Netanyahu had a mafia-style conversation with Arnon Mozes, the editor of Yedioth Ahronoth, even while knowing it was being recorded.
Netanyahu planned blatant quid pro quo transactions with Shaul Elovitch, the former controlling shareholder of Bezeq/Walla.
Netanyahu was willing to sell out the public interest for his personal benefit in two instances.
At the starting line for leadership of the right on the day after Netanyahu, in addition to Bennett there are other players like Ayelet Shaked, Nir Barkat, Yisrael Katz, Yuli Edelstein, Miri Regev and perhaps a few other political figures.
The winner of the right-wing leadership will have at their disposal a newspaper that is willing to grant him or her strong backing like Netanyahu received.
The competitors for the right-wing leadership would do well to remember the cost of the newspaper’s unreserved support.
a84759634c4f482add3c31e9b2457cc3:
Foreign Minister Yair Lapid says those at the top, including former Justice Minister and Public Security Minister Amir Ohana, should not think they are immune from investigation in the NSO police spying scandal.
Lapid suggests that Ohana should be the first one investigated by the commission.
The government will decide whether to establish a government inquiry or a state commission with wider powers within a week.
Lapid defends the police, saying that only criminals will be happy if they are dismantled, but gatekeepers of the law need to follow the rules better than anyone.
Lapid adds that the scandal "clouds Israeli democracy."
da94a29f9424a4d6ad150ecc0f1fd131:
The Jerusalem District Court cancelled a scheduled court hearing for Benjamin Netanyahu's corruption trial due to swirling police phone spying allegations.
Prosecutors have until 2 p.m. Tuesday to respond to questions regarding the illicit phone spying.
The judges will convene Wednesday to discuss how to proceed.
The Israel Police reportedly used the NSO Group's Pegasus spyware to hack into the phones of a wide range of public figures, including associates and family members of Netanyahu, without any judicial oversight or approval.
Those illicitly targeted also said to include activists and demonstrators, mayors, ministry director-generals, journalists and others.
In Case 4000, one of the three graft cases for which Netanyahu is on trial, Netanyahu is alleged to have advanced regulatory decisions that immensely benefited Shaul Elovitch, in exchange for editorial control over the Walla news site.
Jack Chen, an attorney for the Elovitches, said that “for years we have been warning against a flawed and tendentious investigation that crossed all boundaries.”
Avner Netanyahu, the son of the former prime minister, and Netanyahu advisers Yonatan Urich and Topaz Luk had been targeted by police spying.
The Jerusalem District Court gave state prosecutors until Tuesday to answer questions from the defense about police use of spyware in the investigation into Netanyahu.
0c0dfb89b7f56dba0ed80722f2bbb091:
Police Commissioner Kobi Shabtai denied excessive surveillance of civilians and claimed an initial probe found no police wrongdoings.
Shabtai instructed senior officers to investigate allegations of police surveillance of civilians' smartphones using Pegasus spyware.
Shabtai cut short his official visit to the UAE and returned to Israel amid public criticism of his absence during the scandal.
Justice Minister Gideon Saar and other ministers publicly supported a national commission of inquiry to investigate potential police violations.
Calcalist reported that Pegasus spyware was illegally used on dozens of civilians, including public servants not suspected of criminal activity.
Shabtai expressed faith in the credibility of the police force, including intelligence units.
Shabtai emphasized the importance of law enforcement having advanced tools to fight crime and protect public security, but stressed that such tools must be used legally.
Shabtai stated that police investigations are conducted with respect for privacy rights and that the force will continue to operate within democratic values.
e4462acee9525580bdf9d3262050a707:
Likud MK Miri Regev answered a phone call from her mother during a Knesset session on alleged phone hacking by police.
Deputy Speaker Eitan Ginzburg scolded Regev for taking the call, but she continued.
Regev referred to the Israeli firm behind the Pegasus spyware allegedly used to target citizens.
Regev ignored the fact that the alleged spyware hacking took place while she was in government.
Police deployed spyware against senior government officials, mayors, activist leaders, journalists, and former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu's family members and advisers without the required judicial oversight.
A police-run probe said that only three people named in the report on the alleged hacking were in fact targeted, only one of them successfully, and all with judicial approval.
Public Security Minister Omer Barlev presented the results of the probe to Prime Minister Naftali Bennett.
a34075168c2d5babd25b256143239cac:
Former police commissioner Roni Alsheich denied any police wrongdoing under his watch amid the ongoing scandal surrounding the allegedly illegal use of spyware by the police.
Alsheich said the allegations against the force, if true, would have been “a deep blow to democracy, no less,” but insisted that they “have no connection to reality.”
Alsheich said the list of alleged targets of the spyware campaign included names of innocent people police have never suspected of any criminal wrongdoing.
Alsheich stated his utmost trust in the police’s internal investigation of the claims, but also welcomed exhaustive outside examination.
Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said that all allegations “will be looked into from every direction” and that “the wholesale use of [such spyware] against citizens can not be allowed in a democratic country.”
Former attorney general Avichai Mandelblit said he had no connection to the ongoing police spying scandal and did not know if any of it was true.
Labor MK Gilad Kariv said that Alsheich was never the right person to lead the Israel Police.
Yesh Atid MK and Deputy Public Security Minister Yoav Segalovitz criticized allegations made against Alsheich, supporting the former police commissioner.
Police Commissioner Kobi Shabtai continued to deny allegations that officers used spyware illegally against Israeli public and private figures.
Incoming Attorney General Gali Baharav-Miara said that she intends to investigate the allegations, noting that the scandal has led to “an alarming decline of public trust in law enforcement agencies.”
0815ac90c35edb13a65794e70992371e:
Former attorney general Avichai Mandelblit blocked police requests to tap into the phones of former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s son and wife, Yair and Sara Netanyahu.

The unnamed ex-cop says that Mandelblit didn’t authorize the wiretap, and the police kept complaining that they were being handicapped and their hands were being tied.
a313cbb91b5028371e409c01e2a7b851:
State prosecutors said that a police check found no evidence of warrantless wiretapping during the investigation of former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
The prosecution did not comment on how many warrants were executed or whether spyware was used.
The check focused on both standard wiretapping and the use of more “advanced” technologies.
The prosecution requested three more days to complete its check, which is expected to answer questions about the use of court orders.
Defense attorneys said that the prosecution admits to spying on civilians without authorization.
Opposition party leaders rejected the prosecution’s statement and called for a state commission of inquiry.
A separate investigation is looking into whether the police used spy software to break into the phones of 26 people, including figures associated with the trial against Netanyahu.
The Jerusalem District Court postponed two hearings last week to allow investigators to look into the hacking claims.
56453bfddb6cbe638b80ee680ec0cbb2:
All planned sessions this week in former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s ongoing corruption trial will be postponed to Feb 21.
A high-level Israeli inquiry into alleged warrantless wiretaps by police is examining a database provided by NSO Group.
Calcalist newspaper reported that police had used Pegasus without judges' warrants against public figures including a son and two of Netanyahu’s close aides.
The court instructed prosecutors to answer questions from the former premier’s lawyers about the extent of the espionage.
Prosecutors requested that Jerusalem District Court give them until Wednesday to deliver a fuller response, citing a need to declassify materials first.
Police and prosecutors insist that this is a side case and that Netanyahu will not be acquitted.
fc6a13a16854ee14ca88ee86e76f18e4:
Prosecutors in former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s corruption trial revealed that police used spyware to hack the phone of one witness, Shlomo Filber, but no material discovered was used.
The spyware was activated on Filber's phone for about a day, but no material relevant to the case was found.
Lawyers for the defendants and associates of Netanyahu rejected the state prosecutors’ claims and demanded a state commission of inquiry.
The examination focused on both standard wiretapping and the use of more “advanced” technologies.
Figures associated with the trial who supposedly had their phones hacked include Ilan Yeshua, Avner Netanyahu, Filber, Iris Elovitch, Dudu Mizrachi, Stella Hendler, Aviram Elad, and other journalists at Walla.
Netanyahu’s defense lawyers are expected to argue next week in court that the police report the prosecutors relied upon is not credible and that the trial should be delayed until a more in-depth probe into the allegations.
An ongoing separate investigation, headed by Deputy Attorney General Amit Marari, has found that many of the allegations in the original Calcalist news story were false.

0344bb8044643c79e3f22729b11aab92:
Associates of former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu reject claims by state prosecutors that instances of improper spying on witnesses in his corruption trial are irrelevant.

419a8b55062420cdb9903a2b155db359:
State Comptroller Matanyahu Englman is conducting an "in-depth" investigation into claims that Israel Police spied on Israeli citizens.
Englman's probe will involve internal and external experts, including former intelligence officials.
The investigation will examine the use of technological means by law enforcement agencies, including whether there was a deviation from authority and whether legislation and regulation in Israel are prepared to deal with technological progress.
Englman's investigation will also check the information security of data collected by the police.
Deputy Attorney General Amit Marari is also investigating whether police made illicit use of spy software to break into the phones of 26 people.
Marari's investigation has found that most of those named in the Calcalist newspaper report were not targeted.
NSO's Pegasus spyware was not used against three former directors of government ministries: Shai Babad, Keren Terner Eyal, and Emi Palmor.
The prime minister's son, Avner Netanyahu, was also not spied on.
Some individuals named by Calcalist were subjected to police phone hacking via spyware, but they were suspected of criminal activity and the spyware was used with judicial approval.
The European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) has called for a ban on Pegasus spyware within the European Union.
8518fbace17d2a020073bc6b1bc9cde2:
Israeli journalist Tomer Ganon defended his reporting on the police’s alleged illicit use of spyware on civilians, despite growing doubts about its veracity.
Government officials have backpedaled on the allegations, with separate probes by the police and deputy attorney general said to largely debunk the unsourced newspaper claims.
Police and justice officials have so far said their probes have not found evidence of any widespread wrongdoing by police, and some have called on Ganon to provide more information to back up his claims.
An internal police probe claimed that out of the 26 people named by Calcalist to have been illicitly spied on by police, only three of them had been targeted, only one successfully, and all with judicial oversight.
An investigation being overseen by Deputy Attorney General Amit Marari has also found that most of those named in the newspaper report were not targeted.
The prime minister’s son, Avner Netanyahu, also named in the Calcalist report, was also not spied on, the Marari probe has reportedly established.
State Comptroller Matanyahu Englman said Thursday he was carrying out an “in-depth” investigation into the claims against police.
Prosecutors in Netanyahu’s ongoing trial told the Jerusalem District Court on Wednesday that spyware was used by police to hack Filber’s phone, but that no material discovered was used and that trial proceedings should continue as scheduled.
c3f2f5fd95360e3f364dda86dfec3ce4:
The hearings for this week in the ongoing corruption trial of former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu are canceled after Judge Moshe Bar-Am tests positive for COVID.
The court canceled tomorrow’s hearing when it found out that Bar-Am had come in contact with a positive COVID case.
The hearings for the rest of the week are canceled, since Bar-Am will have to remain in quarantine.
The judges in the trial were slated to deal this week with the fallout from the police spying affair incident.
Prosecutors have claimed that allegations that Israel Police illegally spied on witnesses in the case should have no bearing on the trial.

a0543f96db2be79e67ad32507b312152:
Four Palestinians were wounded by rubber-coated metal bullets during clashes with Israeli occupation forces on Jabal Sabih in Beita, south of Nablus.

15 citizens suffocated with tear gas during the confrontations in Beita.
The occupation forces impeded the work of the ambulance crews by closing the roads leading to the confrontation area.

Eight Palestinians died in a collision between a van and a cement truck in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

The victims were not officially identified but local news outlets reported they were teenagers between 14 and 17 years old.
Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas declared a day of mourning to be observed on Friday across the Palestinian territories in honor of the victims.
Israeli Defense Minister Benny Gantz issued a note of sympathy to the Palestinian families who lost their loved ones in the crash.
Neighboring Jordan also expressed condolences.
The victims were workers from the town of Aqraba, near Nablus.
c2c6f005b2bf7c9708500fe8c47b04e8:
Clashes erupted in the West Bank city of Jenin after Palestinian Authority security forces arrested three people, including the son of a terror leader.
The reason for the arrests was unclear.
Video clips showed officers arresting Muhammad Zubeidi and roughing him up, sparking furor in Jenin.
Dozens of armed Jenin residents confronted the PA security forces to oppose the arrests.

Muhammad Zubeidi was released a number of hours later and appeared to have a bandaged head and hand.

The IDF had been poised to launch a large-scale operation in Jenin in recent months, but halted the raid after PA forces were pressured into acting.
The security cooperation between Israel and the PA was a central theme of recent talks when PA President Mahmoud Abbas met with Defense Minister Benny Gantz.
7366a018d051c867de5956c130072e8c:
The Supreme Court ruled that a cleaner paralyzed after falling down an unfenced elevator shaft at a construction site bears no blame for the accident and is entitled to full compensation.
The justices overturned the Haifa District Court’s ruling that the worker also shares some of the blame.
The worker was paralyzed from the waist down after falling four stories down the shaft in 2014.
The Supreme Court ruled that the company owed the worker full compensation since it failed to fence off the elevator shaft and provided the worker with no protective equipment.
The Supreme Court stated that work safety regulations weren’t intended to examine whether the worker is complying with their implementation.
The Supreme Court added that once the employer failed to strictly comply with safety regulations, the employer should not be allowed to point the finger of blame at the worker for failing to demand this.
The worker’s lawyers stated that the ruling is precedent-setting and will affect change in the understanding that ordinary workers can’t be blamed for the failures of the employer.
496f80412f9fd191c370ada0f249d463:
A 19-year-old soldier was struck by a car and wounded in the northern West Bank on Tuesday, in what the military said was a possible car-ramming attack.

The driver was also injured and arrested after crashing into a security barrier.
This event continues the recent uptick of violent attacks by Palestinians in the West Bank and Jerusalem.
Last month a Palestinian man was shot dead who the military says attempted a car-ramming attack near a settlement in the Nablus area.
In early December an Israeli security guard was moderately injured in a car-ramming attack at a checkpoint near the Palestinian town of Tul Karm.
73557f41943c30e85db30bad74132106:
80-year-old Palestinian Omar Abdalmajeed As'ad was found dead after being detained and handcuffed during an Israeli raid on a village in the occupied West Bank.

The Israeli military confirmed that it had carried out an overnight operation in the village, and that a Palestinian was "apprehended after resisting a check."
The Israeli military said he was alive when the soldiers released him.
The Military Police Criminal Investigation Division is reviewing the incident, at the end of which the findings will be transferred to the Military General Advocate Corps.
As'ad's family delayed the funeral until Thursday to allow a post-mortem.
Islam Abu Zaher, a local doctor who said he had tried to resuscitate As'ad but found no pulse, said there were no obvious signs of injury and the cause of death was unclear.
Jiljilya village council head Fouad Qattoum said As'ad was returning home after visiting relatives when Israeli soldiers stopped his car, bound him, blindfolded him and led him away to a building still under construction.
As'ad's body was found more than an hour later.
Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh blamed Israeli forces for the man's death, calling it a "crime."
Israeli military spokesman Lt. Col. Amnon Shefler said the military "will investigate this event in a thorough and professional manner, acting in line with our values and protocols."
fddab354f5bad417295e2093d63843df:
80-year-old Palestinian-American Omar Abd al-Majid As’ad died of a heart attack after being arrested by Israeli soldiers near Ramallah on Wednesday morning.

The US State Department has asked Israel for clarification about the incident and supports a thorough investigation.
Tensions have been rising between Israel and the Palestinians across the West Bank and Gaza over the past month, including a wave of terror attacks that so far have taken the lives of two Israeli civilians and wounded several others.

The 19-year-old soldier was injured in his legs and evacuated by military helicopter to Hadassah Ein Kerem hospital in Yerushalayim.

85cf94b4a451713044fc18e577da530a:
80-year-old Palestinian man Omar Abdalmajeed As'ad died of a heart attack after being detained overnight by Israeli forces in the Ramallah area.
As'ad was "assaulted" and beaten by Israeli soldiers, who stopped him on his way home, in the village of Jiljilya, and handcuffed him.
As'ad was a dual U.S. citizen.

c5352f3e62c1ed9cdb7e7c2bd49b357c:
An 80-year-old Palestinian, Omar Abdulmajeed Asad, was found dead in a village in the occupied West Bank early Wednesday, his body still handcuffed after an Israeli arrest raid.
Around 30 to 40 Israeli troops took part in the pre-dawn operation in the village of Jiljiliya, north of Ramallah.
Asad and other family members were returning from visiting relatives when they were stopped by the soldiers and arrested.
After the troops withdrew, villagers found Asad's body in a building under construction.
The Palestinian health ministry confirmed that Assad had died of a "heart attack".
Clashes break out frequently in Palestinian population centers in the West Bank when Israeli troops mount incursions to carry out arrests.
Israel has occupied the territory since the Six-Day War of 1967.
Excluding annexed east Jerusalem, some 475,000 Israelis live in settlements in the West Bank regarded as illegal under international law, alongside more than 2.9 million Palestinians.
3c62ae2589073e6a747f3b233d074a1e:

The mayor of the village of Jiljiliya said Asad's body was still in handcuffs after his death.
Israel said it had apprehended a man during a raid in the village to "thwart terrorist activity" and that he had been released the same night.

Clashes break out frequently in Palestinian population centers in the West Bank when Israeli troops mount incursions to carry out arrests.
Israel has occupied the territory since the Six-Day War of 1967.
Excluding annexed east Jerusalem, some 475,000 Israelis live in settlements in the West Bank regarded as illegal under international law, alongside more than 2.9 million Palestinians.
President Joe Biden's administration has returned to past US criticism of settlement building after former president Donald Trump offered unstinting support to the US ally.
22560ba4e7c00609d996b78b02e63a66:
Omar Asaad, an 80-year-old Palestinian with U.S. citizenship, died of a heart attack after being detained by Israeli soldiers in the occupied West Bank.

Jaljulia Mayor Fouad Qattum said the soldiers stopped Asaad's vehicle and removed him by force shortly before dawn.
