The Palestinian attempted to stab an Israeli soldier at Gush Etzion junction north of Hebron.
No injuries were reported among Israeli soldiers.
The Palestinian Health Ministry identified the dead Palestinian as Faleh Jaradat from Sa'ir town, northeast of Hebron city.
e7747e5d3184f24450f5b2e2433f9b12:
A Palestinian man was shot dead as he attempted to stab soldiers at a bus stop in the central West Bank on Monday.
The Palestinian man got out of a car, armed with a knife, and tried to stab an IDF soldier.
The soldier opened fire at the man, killing him.
The knife was recovered at the scene.
Troops launched a search to find the car that transported the assailant to the scene.
The driver of the vehicle turned himself in to Israeli security forces.
The assailant was identified by the Palestinian Authority as Faleh Mousa Shakir Jaradat, from the village of Seir near Hebron.
The soldiers guarding the bus stop were reservists, who were deployed to the area last week.
The attempted attack came amid a general lull in attacks by Palestinians against Israeli soldiers and civilians in the West Bank.
3d56252a620d8c1bf2864f7329f7a1ab:
A tow truck driver who ran over and fatally injured a Palestinian man in the West Bank two weeks ago has yet to be questioned by the police.
The Palestinian, 65-year-old Suleiman Hathalin, died of his injuries on Monday.
Hathalin was a well-known protester in the area.
Palestinian witnesses to the incident in the village of Umm al-Kheir in the South Hebron Hills have also yet to be questioned.
Hathalin’s son said that the police refused to accept his complaint against the tow truck driver and told him to file it with the Justice Ministry’s police misconduct unit.
A photo of the scene taken by Palestinians minutes before Hathalin was run over shows a policeman with a body camera.
However, replying to a Haaretz inquiry about footage of the incident, the police said the police had not had cameras at the time.
About an hour prior to the incident, the driver posted a video on his Facebook page that appears to have been taken from a dashboard-mounted camera from the truck.
The police have also not responded to Haaretz’s question regarding whether police officers at the scene of the incident would be questioned.
Following the incident, the tow truck and a police vehicle fled the scene without coming to Al-Hathalin’s assistance.
The police said they are investigating the incident with input from the State Prosecutor’s Office.
16773066184eab6c48e30f9f6ebab632:
Rabbi Charlie Cytron-Walker and three congregants were held hostage for nearly 11 hours in Congregation Beth Israel in Colleyville, Texas.
The FBI named Malik Faisal Akram, a 44-year-old British citizen, as the perpetrator.
Akram was shot dead by an FBI SWAT team.
25d1dac762232bb4011e0869dc105292:
Palestinians held a funeral procession for Fahmi Hamad, a 57-year-old man who died of tear gas inhalation during an Israeli raid on a refugee camp north of the city of al-Quds.
Israeli forces stormed the Qalandiya camp on Monday, firing a barrage of gas bombs and rubber-coated steel bullets at Palestinians, who protested the raid, as well as a clinic run by the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA).
Hamad suffered from severe effects of tear gas inhalation while inside the UNRWA clinic and was rushed to a hospital in the occupied West Bank city Ramallah, but he succumbed to his wounds.
Israeli forces frequently storm Palestinian neighborhoods in the occupied territories, often using live fire and tear gas to crack down on any act of protest against their presence.
The Institute for National Security Studies (INSS) warned that the absence of a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict “poses a serious threat” to Tel Aviv’s status on the international stage.
The INSS said that the security situation in the West Bank is nearing a boiling point due to the weakness of the Palestinian Authority in the face of united opposition from various factions and street gangs.
The INSS also asserted that in the besieged Gaza Strip, “Israel currently faces the same complex and long-lasting dilemma: the need for an urgent response to the humanitarian situation, while avoiding security escalation.”
aba27422a51fef2f8b93c9dcb62b7180:
Palestinian Omar As’ad, 78, likely died from a stress-induced heart attack caused by the circumstances of his detention by Israeli soldiers, according to an official Palestinian Authority autopsy.
Israel is under American pressure to investigate the death of As’ad, who was also a United States citizen.
As’ad was detained by Israeli soldiers as he drove through his hometown at 3 a.m. on a frigid January night.
As’ad was tied up and blindfolded by Israeli soldiers.
As’ad was found dead of a heart attack in a half-constructed building an hour after Israeli troops left the scene.
The Israeli military has opened an investigation into the incident.
Palestinians and left-wing groups have long been critical of Israeli military investigations, which they say rarely bring results.
US State Department spokesperson Ned Price said that Washington would ask for “clarification” from Israel over As’ad’s death.
a92b6de5bb5990c434372c94a6016808:
An elderly Palestinian-American, Omar Abdalmajeed As'ad, was found dead after being detained by Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank.
A Palestinian autopsy report released Wednesday stated that As'ad suffered sudden cardiac arrest caused by the stress of being manhandled.
The autopsy report also noted that As'ad had a history of heart problems.
The Israeli military said on Wednesday that it had no immediate comment on the findings.
An Israeli military statement on 12 January said that its forces carried out an overnight operation in the village, and that a Palestinian was "apprehended after resisting a check".
The statement said he was alive when the soldiers released him, but that the Military Police Criminal Investigation Division was reviewing the incident.
As'ad was found with a plastic zip-tie around one wrist.
As'ad had lived in the United States for decades and returned to the West Bank 10 years ago.
The US State Department said that As'ad was a US citizen and that it had sought clarification on the case from Israel.
dbe427ec4d28eb3caf2156e92a3350a5:
Israeli forces injured dozens of Palestinians protesting against Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.
Israeli forces suppressed a weekly anti-settlement rally in Kafr Qaddum, using rubber bullets and tear gas, injuring four Palestinians, including a child and a journalist.
Dozens of Palestinians suffered breathing difficulties due to tear gas fired by Israeli troops during clashes on Sobeih Mountain in the town of Beita.
Israeli forces attacked Palestinians taking part in a peaceful anti-settlement protest in the village of Beit Dajan, injuring 15 Palestinians with rubber bullets and causing breathing difficulties for nine others due to tear gas.
Clashes erupted in the area of Bab a-Zawiyah in the center of al-Khalil (Hebron) as Israeli forces fired rubber bullets, sound bombs, and tear gas at Palestinians, causing breathing difficulties for tens of Palestinians.
Israel occupied the West Bank and the Gaza Strip during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War in 1967.
Over 600,000 Israelis live in over 230 settlements built since the 1967 occupation of the Palestinian territories of the West Bank.
All the settlements are illegal under international law.
The United Nations Security Council has condemned the settlement activities in several resolutions.
fc6f46dbd9439b6e0ac12989ce4e8852: Omar As’ad, an 80-year-old Palestinian, died after being wounded during his arrest by Israeli soldiers north of Ramallah about three weeks ago.
The death of Omar As’ad is emerging as one of the most serious incidents in the West Bank in recent years.
ed9a6a0b1e25176304d7045a2e029331:
Israel’s military is dismissing two officers and reprimanding a battalion commander over the death of an elderly Palestinian, Omar Abdalmajeed As’ad, on January 12.
As’ad, who was also a US national, was found dead after being detained by Israeli troops in Jiljilya village in the occupied West Bank.
A Palestinian autopsy found As’ad, who had pre-existing heart conditions, had suffered sudden cardiac arrest caused by the stress of being manhandled.
The military said As’ad had refused to cooperate with troops operating in the area and that “his hands were tied and he was gagged for a short time.”
The investigation concluded that the incident was a grave and unfortunate event, resulting from a moral failure and poor decision-making on the part of the soldiers.
A core value of the Israeli military — to protect human life — had been violated.
The soldiers failed in their obligations by leaving As’ad lying on the floor without the required treatment and without reporting the incident back to their commanders.
Palestinian leaders have called for the soldiers involved to be prosecuted in an international court.
31bf0902bfbe8d0193f301047a855b03:
A military investigation into the death of 80-year-old Palestinian Omar Abdalmajeed As'ad shows a grave "moral lapse" by the soldiers involved.
As'ad was detained by soldiers belonging to the Netzah Yehuda battalion and died after being handcuffed, gagged and forced to lie on his stomach in the cold while in custody.
The investigation found that the soldiers' decision to leave As'ad without checking on him goes against the IDF's moral obligations.
IDF officials said the officers had created an "enabling atmosphere" for such incidents to occur and failed to enforce discipline.
The commander of the Netzah Yehuda battalion will be rebuked, and two subordinate company and platoon commanders will be immediately dismissed.
Three soldiers involved in the incident, and their platoon commander, are expected to be questioned on Tuesday by military police.
According to partial findings from the autopsy report, submitted by the Palestinians, As'ad died from a heart attack.
Three Palestinian doctors who conducted the autopsy determined that As'ad's heart attack was caused by stress, after he was subjected to “external violence.”
f855d8e51f1fecc9e43d196dc6227de4:
The US demands a thorough criminal investigation and full accountability for the death of Omar As'ad, a 78-year-old Palestinian-American man who died after being bound, gagged and abandoned by Israeli soldiers.
The Israeli military's internal investigation concluded that the soldiers "showed a clear lapse of moral judgment" and a failure to "protect the sanctity of any human life" in the death of Omar As'ad.
The US continues to discuss this troubling incident with the Israeli government.
Disciplinary action is being taken by the Israeli army against the battalion commander and other officers responsible for the unit involved.
A Military Police investigation into the As'ad's death is ongoing.
As'ad was detained by soldiers from the Netzah Yehuda Battalion who set up an impromptu checkpoint in the central West Bank village of Jiljilya.
As'ad was tackled by the troops, who then bound his hands with zip ties and moved him to a nearby construction site, where he was left on the ground in the near-freezing January night.
The soldiers also gagged As'ad, first with their hands and then by tying a strip of fabric over his mouth for a short amount of time.
As'ad was found dead a few hours later with one zip tie still around one of his hands and a blindfold over his eyes.
An autopsy conducted by the Palestinian Authority and reviewed by the IDF determined that he had died of a stress-induced heart attack, brought on by being tackled to the ground, bound and gagged.
1f1171e13432ebb5caa635588b6f3157:
Defense Minister Benny Gantz expressed sorrow at the death of a 78-year-old Palestinian man, Omar As’ad, who suffered heart failure after being bound, gagged and abandoned at a construction site in the middle of winter by Israeli soldiers last month.
Gantz said the Israel Defense Forces would take action against any “deviations” from its values.
IDF Chief of Staff Aviv Kohai and head of the IDF Central Command Maj. Gen. Yehuda Fuchs also condemned the soldiers’ actions.
According to an IDF probe, on January 12, soldiers from the Netzah Yehuda Battalion set up an impromptu checkpoint in the central West Bank village of Jiljilya, stopping cars and checking the identification documents of people inside.
As’ad was the first to pass through the checkpoint and refused to identify himself when asked and yelled at the soldiers.
The soldiers tackled As’ad to the ground and bound his hands with zip ties, then moved him to a nearby construction site, where he was left on the ground in the near-freezing January night.
The soldiers also gagged As’ad to prevent him from calling out and telling others about the checkpoint.
When the Netzah Yehuda soldiers decided to pack up the checkpoint roughly half an hour later, they untied the four Palestinians and let them go.
By that time, As’ad was unresponsive. The soldiers left him on the ground at the construction site.
As’ad, an American citizen who had lived in the US for many years, was found dead a few hours later with one ziptie still around one of his hands and a blindfold over his eyes.
An autopsy conducted by the Palestinian Authority and reviewed by the IDF determined that As’ad had died of a stress-induced heart attack, brought on by being tackled to the ground, bound and gagged.
Kohavi said the soldiers’ decision to leave As’ad on the ground in the freezing night was “grave and unethical.”
Fuchs similarly denounced the decision, as well as the initial choice to violently detain As’ad.
Gantz also called for the IDF, Shin Bet and police to crackdown on “nationalistic crime and Jewish terror” in the West Bank.
The past year saw a major rise in violent attacks by Israeli extremists against Palestinians and, to a lesser extent, against Israeli left-wing activists and security forces.
Gantz has called for the military and law enforcement to take a harsher stance against this violence.
Gantz met with Shin Bet chief Ronen Bar and the head of the police’s West Bank division, Uzi Levi, to receive an update on the ongoing joint effort to combat “nationalistic crime.”
94ca61ef76d26cd109314c9b3e757554:
The head of the military’s Central Command condemned soldiers for leaving an elderly Palestinian man on the ground at a construction site, where he subsequently died of heart failure, after they detained him in the middle of the night.
Central Command chief Maj. Gen. Yehuda Fuchs described the incident as an “extremely grave ethical failure” and said the officers involved should have used greater discretion in deciding to detain the 78-year-old man, Omar As’ad, in the first place as well as to then leave him unconscious in a half-constructed building.
IDF Chief of Staff Aviv Kohavi similarly denounced the soldiers’ actions on Tuesday in remarks made to officers preparing to become company and battalion commanders.
According to an Israel Defense Forces probe presented to IDF Chief of Staff Aviv Kohavi on Monday, a group of some 30 soldiers from the Netzah Yehuda Battalion set up an impromptu checkpoint in the central West Bank village of Jiljilya on January 12, stopping cars and checking the identification documents of people inside.
As’ad, an American citizen who had lived in the US for many years, was found dead a few hours later with one ziptie still around one of his hands and a blindfold over his eyes.
An autopsy conducted by the Palestinian Authority determined that he had died of a stress-induced heart attack, brought on by being bound and gagged.
The Central Command chief said their decision to leave him, unconscious on the ground in the middle of a near-freezing winter night, was not made out of malice, but because “they cared more about completing their mission” than about ensuring As’ad’s well-being.
In the wake of the probe, two junior officers were dismissed from their positions and barred from command roles for the next two years, and the commander of the Netzah Yehuda Battalion will be formally censured.
Fuchs defended the decision to not take disciplinary action against the soldiers involved in As’ad’s death, saying the responsibility was ultimately the commanders’.
Fuchs also defended the decision to set up an impromptu checkpoint inside the village, saying the practice has allowed soldiers to arrest terrorist operatives, find weapons and otherwise prevent attacks.
c4cecf29ef15ef2002eb4e9de59d23aa:
Omar As’ad, a 78-year-old Palestinian-American, died after Israeli troops stopped him at a checkpoint in his native village of Jiljilya on January 12.
As’ad’s family members said that the soldiers dragged him out of his car, threw him to the ground, and shackled his hands and feet with zip ties, then fled after he died on the spot.
The Israeli military completed an internal probe that ruled that two officers will be removed from their positions immediately and a third will be formally censured over the death.
US Sen. Tammy Baldwin and Rep. Gwen Moore sent a letter to US Secretary of State Antony Blinken asking him to launch an investigation into Assad’s death and whether the soldiers involved used equipment procured with American aid.
State Department spokesman Ned Price said that the agency hasn’t seen a final report from Israeli officials.
As’ad was born in Jiljilya but spent about 40 years in the United States. He became a US citizen before he returned to his home village in 2009 to retire with his wife.
6387c7024836c6d9d3af35a48062f0e3:
Judge Haim Liran sentenced policemen Baruch Peretz and Assaf Yekutieli for abandoning prisoner Omar Abu Jariban on the side of the road, leading to his death from dehydration.
The incident involving Omar Abu Jariban occurred four years before the Elor Azaria affair, where a soldier confirmed the kill of Abdel Fattah al-Sharif.
Four years after the Elor Azaria affair, Eyad Hallaq, a young man with autism, was shot seven times by Border Police forces.
The investigation into the death of 80-year-old Omar Abdalmajeed As’ad revealed a moral failure and error in judgment by the troops, undermining the value of human dignity.
The lead editorial and an op-ed demanded the disbandment of the Netzah Yehuda battalion, but the article argues that this will not address the broader culture of violence and abuse within the IDF, Israel Police, and Border Police.
0e73a733ae6524c540672a012c0c831e:
The deputy head of the battalion involved in a friendly fire incident during which two Border Police officers were lightly wounded was removed from his post.
The deputy commander of the Caracal Brigade erred in failing to coordinate aspects of the drug smuggling operation and violating open-fire weapon regulations.
The battalions involved were ordered to study and simulate the incident to ensure that it doesn’t happen again.
The head of the IDF’s Southern Command said that the drug smuggling that takes place on the Egyptian border poses a criminal problem with broader security ramifications.
IDF chief of staff Aviv Kohavi characterized the incident as a “serious and unnecessary [one] that should have been avoided.”
There were at least nine smuggling attempts along the Egyptian border overnight, making it “one of the most active nights on the Egyptian border in recent memory.”
The IDF and Israel Police seized some 400 kilograms (880 pounds) of drugs, worth an estimated NIS 8 million ($2.5 million), over the course of the night.
Smugglers on the Egyptian side of the border drove up to the security fence in armored vehicles, with machine guns on top, and opened fire “massively” into Israeli territory.
The Caracal soldiers opened fire at the tires of a Border Police vehicle, believing it was a truck being used by the Israeli smugglers to collect the packages of drugs.
2a4a3e0221072468a657ae1d20b72ecb:
Israel's public security minister has called for an investigation into the Israel Police's use of hard sponge-tipped bullets against Bedouin during protests last month.
Five Bedouin suffered head injuries during protests over the planting of JNF trees.
The Justice Ministry has told the public security minister that the matter is being examined.
A 16-year-old Bedouin boy lost an eye after being hit by a sponge-tipped bullet.
In 2000, police use of rubber-coated bullets to disperse demonstrations was outlawed.
The police loosened restrictions on the use of hard sponge-tipped bullets in June of last year.
dee1e3cd1ec05acefd0349c72c8c3b67:
Israel confirmed that its forces killed three Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank during an alleged "operation to thwart a terror cell."
The three Palestinians were "armed terrorists who were ... killed during clashes with the security forces," according to Israel's Border Police.
The Palestinian Ministry of Health said that Israeli soldiers shot dead three Palestinian men in al-Makhfeya neighborhood in the city of Nablus.
Israel's Shin Bet security service claimed that the three killed Palestinians were responsible for several recent shooting attacks against the Israel Defense Forces and Israeli civilians.
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett tweeted that "those who harm us will be harmed."
Palestine called on the international community to investigate the Israeli killing.
The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, an armed wing of the Fatah movement led by Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, claimed that the three men are members of the group and "heroic martyrs."
Recent weeks have seen a sharp rise in violence of Jewish settlers against the Palestinians and Palestinian property in the West Bank, as well as Palestinian attacks against Israeli forces and settlers.
f8bc60706af326f159fcfad9611dcdcb:
Thousands of Palestinians participated in the funeral of three terror suspects killed by Israeli forces in an ambush in Nablus.
Israeli security forces shot and killed the three Palestinians during an operation in Nablus’ al-Makhfiya neighborhood.
Israeli defense officials said the three belonged to a terror cell that had conducted shooting attacks against Israeli military posts and personnel over the past few weeks.
Palestinian media reports identified the gunmen as Ashraf al-Mubaslit, Adham Mabrouk and Muhammad al-Dakhil, and said they were affiliated with the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades terror group.
A Fatah spokesperson confirmed that the three Palestinians were Fatah members.
A fourth Palestinian suspect, Ibrahim Nabulsi, was originally reported to have been killed in the raid as well, but is still at large.
Armed men, some masked, could be seen marching in the procession during the funeral; some fired bursts of bullets into the air.
The Al-Aqsa Martyrs’ Brigades vowed revenge for its members’ deaths.
Arab Israeli politicians condemned the operation as an “execution.”
The Joint List bloc of parties released a statement calling the shooting deaths of the three Palestinians “a crime against the Palestinian people.”
Israeli police denied that the operation was a targeted killing, saying that officers from the counter-terrorism Yamam unit first sought to arrest the suspects.
An Israeli security official said the Palestinian suspects were on their way to commit another attack, necessitating their intervention.
The Palestinian Authority cabinet called for an international investigation.
489678958755e6f10802f1809424a17e:
Israeli special forces killed three Palestinians and arrested another in the city of Nablus in the northern part of the occupied West Bank.
The victims were identified as Ibrahim al-Nablusi, Adham Mabrouk, and Muhammed al-Dakhil, members of the West Bank-based resistance group Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
The Israeli regime accused the targeted Palestinians of “several shooting attacks” over the past weeks.
The Palestinian Authority’s health ministry called the Israeli operation "an assassination."
Hamas urged all Palestinian groups to stage an “intense reprisal” and called for mass participation in the funeral of the three Palestinians.
Hamas official Jasem al-Barghouti said the atrocity proved that resistance was the only option that could protect the Palestinian nation.
Israel’s Minister for Military Affairs, Benny Gantz praised the Israeli military and other participating organizations over the criminal operation.
0e5d904a07100bc8268e3c98f6507326:
Israel claimed that three Palestinians killed in the West Bank are "armed terrorists."
The Palestinian Ministry of Health said that Israeli soldiers shot dead three Palestinian men in al-Makhfeya neighborhood in the city of Nablus.
Israel's Shin Bet security service claimed that the three killed Palestinians were responsible for several recent shooting attacks against the Israel Defense Forces and Israeli civilians.
Palestine called on the international community to investigate the Israeli killing.
The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, an armed wing of the Fatah movement led by Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, claimed that the three men are members of the group and "heroic martyrs."
Recent weeks have seen a sharp rise in violence of Jewish settlers against the Palestinians and Palestinian property in the West Bank, as well as Palestinian attacks against Israeli forces and settlers.
411995cf67f84899e2fdf9f7e275b911:
Thousands of Palestinians marched in the Israeli-occupied West Bank for the funeral of three Palestinians, who were assassinated earlier by the Israeli regime’s forces.
The funeral took place in the northern city of Nablus on Tuesday, hours after an Israeli special forces’ detachment killed the victims and arrested a fourth there.
Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade identified the victims as the West Bank-based resistance group’s members, naming them as Ibrahim al-Nablusi, Adham Mabrouk, and Muhammed al-Dakhil.
The Israeli newspaper Ha’aretz reported that the occupying regime has accused the targeted Palestinians of “several shooting attacks” over the past weeks.
The West Bank-based Palestinian Authority’s health ministry called the Israeli operation "an assassination."
Hamas, the resistance movement that is headquartered in the nearby Palestinian territory of the Gaza Strip, urged all Palestinian groups to stage an “intense reprisal.”
Israel’s minister for military affairs, Benny Gantz praised the Israeli military and other participating organizations over the criminal operation, which he described as "preventive" and "proactive".
8c88bcfd2e0d5b9469bd303a1c8322ce:
Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian man near the northern West Bank town of Jenin.
The identity of the slain Palestinian was not immediately announced, and there were no reports of injuries to the Israeli forces.
The incident came days after a weekend of intensified Israel-Palestinian violence across the West Bank, sparked by the death of a Jewish settler who was shot dead by at least one Palestinian gunman.
The death of Yehuda Dimentman ignited a string of settler retaliation attacks, leaving at least three Palestinians requiring hospital treatment.
After a three-day manhunt, the Israeli military announced on Sunday it had arrested four Palestinians they believed to have taken part in the shooting.
Israel captured the West Bank and east Jerusalem in the 1967 Mideast war.
More than 700,000 Jewish settlers live in the territories, which are sought by the Palestinians as parts of a future state.
Palestinians, along with the majority of the international community, consider settlements to be illegal and the major obstacle to peace.
f928aa59a45bd7252be2a2c7e2749483:
Over 150 Palestinians have been injured in Israeli attacks across occupied Palestinian West Bank cities.
Eight of the wounded were journalists and two others were paramedics stationed in the field to help the injured.
The Palestine Red Crescent Society (PRCS) reported that 80 Palestinians were wounded in the cities of Nablus and Qalqilya.
24 others were wounded during protests against the Israeli appropriation of private Palestinian lands on Sbaih Mountain, located in the neighbourhood of Beita.
The Israeli occupation army also cracked down on two peaceful Palestinian demonstrations.
The Israeli occupation used live ammunition, rubber bullets and tear gas canisters.
The PRCS reported that its paramedics treated 45 Palestinians in Beit Dajan, including eight wounded by live ammunition, two paramedics and three journalists.
In Qalqilya, the Israeli occupation forces wounded 11 Palestinians with rubber bullets during clashes.
Two people were wounded in Hebron.
No one was injured after the Israeli occupation drones dropped tear gas canisters.
c9c1ea620a6a66318019e47a8ed0a46f:
A Palestinian teen, Mohammad Akram Ali Taher Abu Salah, 17, was killed during a firefight between Israeli troops and gunmen in the West Bank.
The Israeli military stated that troops came under fire and shot at armed Palestinians.
The Palestinian Red Crescent reported four Palestinians were wounded during the clashes.
The Al-Quds Brigades, the armed wing of Islamic Jihad, claimed responsibility for the shooting attack on IDF troops.
The IDF reported one soldier was moderately injured when a wall in the house collapsed.
The troops entered Silat al-Harithiya to demolish a floor of a home where terror suspect Mahmoud Jaradat lived.
Jaradat is charged with killing Yehuda Dimentman in a deadly West Bank terror shooting in mid-December.
Israel demolishes the homes of Palestinians accused of carrying out deadly terror attacks as a matter of policy.
Tensions have been rising across the West Bank over the past few months, with repeated "lone wolf" attacks and gunfire incidents.
Last Tuesday, Israeli undercover police killed three Palestinians during a raid in Nablus, who were later claimed by the Al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades.
84e8e2a3d6c4ebef7a1d98d4e33158ca:
Israeli troops shot dead a 17-year-old Palestinian, Akram Abu Salah, during clashes in the occupied West Bank.
Clashes erupted after Israeli forces destroyed homes of two Palestinian detainees accused of killing a settler in December.
Unrest took place in Sheikh Jarrah, Jerusalem, where dozens of Palestinian families are at risk of eviction by Jewish settler organizations.
Itamar Ben-Gvir, an ultranationalist lawmaker, set up a makeshift office near the home of a family facing possible eviction, leading to clashes with Palestinians.
Riot police used putrid-smelling water and stun grenades to break up Palestinian protests, resulting in 14 Palestinian injuries and 12 arrests.
Ben-Gvir accused police of "extreme brutality" against his followers.
Thousands of Palestinians in east Jerusalem face the threat of home demolitions due to discriminatory policies.
Threatened evictions and home demolitions have sparked protests and clashes in the past, including those that ignited the Gaza war in May 2021.
Israel captured east Jerusalem in the 1967 Mideast war and later annexed it, a move not recognized by the international community.
The fate of east Jerusalem is a divisive issue in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
dc9c99c6a3b7dea241b8a34586242271: Security forces entered a village to raze part of the home of Mahmoud Jaradat, a member of the terrorist squad behind the killing of 20-year-old Israeli Yehuda Dimentman last December.
e53b0d3e8dcda24dd9c5420215f016a1:
The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry announces that a Palestinian man was shot dead by Israeli soldiers during clashes in Nabi Saleh.
Fatah identifies the deceased as Nouhad Amin al-Barghouti.
The Israeli army says that “violent clashes” broke out in the area of Nabi Saleh, and the IDF “responded with live fire to disperse the demonstrations.”
11f1f1177641bd795315aec783da3750:
A Palestinian man, Nihad Amin al-Barghouti, was shot dead by Israeli soldiers near Nabi Saleh.
Al-Barghouti previously served a term in Israeli jail for security offenses.
The Israeli military said troops fired on “dozens of Palestinians” who approached a reinforced army post and threw stones at soldiers.
A Palestinian witness said only a handful of Palestinians approached the tower and the soldiers descended from the tower and fired one shot.
Al-Barghouti’s death comes as tensions between Israel and the Palestinians have risen across the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
Clashes have erupted for the past several nights in the flashpoint East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah.
Israeli troops raided Al-Quds University in Abu Dis to break up a protest against the Sheikh Jarrah evictions.
On Sunday night, a firefight broke out between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians in the town of Silat al-Harithiya, near Jenin.
A 17-year-old Palestinian was killed during the clashes.
Last week, Israeli undercover police killed three Palestinians during a rare daytime raid in the West Bank city of Nablus.
8ffe088936f370c94944f74959b0a2a5:
Israeli forces shot and killed a 19-year-old Palestinian youth, Nehad Bargouthi, during a rally in the occupied West Bank village of Nabi Saleh.
Bargouthi was shot in the abdomen with live bullets and succumbed to his wounds in the hospital.
The killing comes a day after Israeli soldiers killed a Palestinian teenage boy and wounded at least 14 others in Silat al-Harithiya Village.
The Israeli regime continues its arrest and demolition spree across the occupied West Bank, amid ongoing clashes between regime forces and Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah.
The European Union (EU) demanded an end to the violent clashes between Israeli military forces and the Palestinian residents of Sheikh Jarrah.
Tensions heightened across the Palestinian territories on Sunday when Israeli forces and illegal settlers renewed their attacks against the Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah.
Israeli settler organizations have claimed ownership of land in Sheikh Jarrah and have been attempting to evict Palestinians from the area.
Most of the international community considers the Israeli settlement structures to be illegal under international law due to their construction on occupied territory.
e943f6a5479aa79cc894cfbb9756f3bb:
Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian man, Nihad al-Barghouti, 20, in the occupied West Bank during a violent confrontation.
The Israeli military said dozens of Palestinians hurled rocks at soldiers stationed at an army post near the village of Nabi Saleh, and the soldiers responded with live fire to stop a suspect.
An eye witness said a group of about 10 Palestinians, some of whom were throwing stones, had started marching toward the soldiers near the village entrance when the troops opened fire.
The Palestinian Health Ministry said Nihad al-Barghouti sustained two bullet wounds around his pelvis.
Palestinians in Nabi Saleh have for years protested against land seizures by Israel, leading to confrontations with the Israeli military and Jewish settlers.
Most countries consider Israeli settlements in occupied territory to be illegal, but Israel disputes this, citing historical, biblical and political ties to the land.
Peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians broke down in 2014.
The Palestinians seek to establish a state in the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip, with East Jerusalem as its capital - all territories Israel captured in a war in 1967.
80852f0d620807f8420d3eda8678afe1:
A 72-year-old Palestinian shepherd, Mohammed Shalalda, was attacked by settlers in Mount Qanub, leaving him with head and facial injuries.
A female soldier bandaged Shalalda's wounds and hugged him, offering a moment of compassion amidst the violence.
Shalalda expressed gratitude for the soldier's care, but emphasized that the attack was a result of the settlers' presence and violence.
The author criticizes the Israeli government and society for supporting the settlers and their actions, stating that the blood of the shepherd is on the hands of all Israelis.
The author warns against being misled by the image of the compassionate soldier, as it is an anomaly and does not represent the reality of the situation.
dff8879db796b966b3ffc241c17dd164:
A 12-year-old Palestinian boy, Rayan Yousef Hamayel, was shot in the head by Israeli soldiers during a protest against an illegal Israeli outpost in the northern West Bank.
Rayan was shot in the back of his head by a rubber-coated steel bullet, fracturing his skull.
Twenty-two other Palestinians were injured during the protest, mostly from tear gas inhalation.
Israeli troops suppressed the protest using riot dispersal measures, including rubber-tipped bullets.
The Israeli government has reached an agreement with settler families to vacate the outpost in exchange for the army leaving illegally erected mobile homes intact and installing a permanent military presence.
The Biden administration has raised concerns over the matter, stating that settlement activity exacerbates tensions and undercuts efforts to advance a negotiated two-state solution.
Hundreds of Israeli left-wing activists protested against the planned compromise deal with settlers to legalize the outpost.
Police stopped marchers from ascending a hill to the outpost, which has been declared a closed military zone.
Palestinians held Friday prayers in Sheikh Jarrah in a common form of protest over the past year.
Police bolstered Sheikh Jarrah, Jerusalem’s Old City and the Damascus Gate area with additional officers and Border Police troops after Prime Minister Naftali Bennett held a Thursday assessment on the tensions.
The Biden administration is particularly concerned about tensions in Jerusalem bubbling over in April, which will see a confluence of the Jewish holiday of Passover, the Muslim holy month of Ramadan and the Christian holiday of Easter.
2b64a19c0c929a64c34617282179738d:
Dozens of Palestinians were injured by Israeli forces in the town of Beita, near Nablus, as clashes erupted after Israeli settlers stormed the area.
Nearly 90 Palestinians, including four journalists, were injured during clashes with Israeli forces in Beita.
57 people suffered breathing difficulties due to inhaling tear gas fired by Israeli troops, and five others were hit with rubber bullets.
Ja’far Shtayyeh was identified as one of the journalists who were injured while covering the clashes.
Clashes erupted on Friday at dawn as Israeli forces attacked Palestinians protesting a visit by Israeli settlers to the area.
Israeli forces had earlier razed roads that led to Sobeih Mountain to block Palestinians from reaching the area.
Since May, Beita has seen intensified clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians protesting against a settlement outpost on Sobeih Mountain.
16 Palestinians were injured in clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians in the village of Beit Dajan.
Israeli forces suppressed a weekly anti-settlement rally in the village of Kafr Qaddum, injuring a 12-year-old boy.
Scores of Palestinians suffered breathing difficulties due to inhaling tear gas fired by Israeli forces.
Israel occupied the West Bank and the Gaza Strip during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War in 1967.
Over 600,000 Israelis live in over 230 settlements built since the 1967 occupation of the Palestinian territories of the West Bank.
All the settlements are illegal under international law.
The United Nations Security Council has condemned the settlement activities in several resolutions.
2125c300f793eec2bc31277eae4970c4:
A 14-year-old Palestinian teen, Muhammad Shahada, was shot dead by Israeli troops while allegedly throwing Molotov cocktails at passing cars near the West Bank city of Bethlehem.
Israeli soldiers provided first aid to Muhammad Shahada on the scene, but he died of his injuries shortly thereafter.
The Israel Defense Forces said the three suspects, including Shahada, were responsible for a string of local firebomb attacks.
Former Khader town mayor Adnan Sbeih said he heard the shooting and rushed out of his home, which lies on the outskirts of the town near the scene of the ambush.
Ahmad Salah, Muhammad’s cousin, told The Times of Israel that he believed Shahada was nowhere near close enough to the wall to threaten Israelis.
The West Bank has seen a rise in violent confrontations between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians in recent weeks.
Two Palestinians were shot last week during confrontations with Israeli forces.
Israeli undercover police killed three Palestinians during a rare daytime raid in the West Bank city of Nablus earlier this month.
e541888fd97f3bc48ba06b0a589054b0:
Israeli soldiers shot a Palestinian man who threw an explosive device from his car at a West Bank checkpoint, seriously wounding the man.
The Palestinian Health Ministry said the man was rushed to a hospital in Jenin with serious gunshot wounds to the back.
The Israeli military said the man threw the explosive device at the soldiers while inside a passing car, but did not hit the force.
On Tuesday, a 14-year-old Palestinian was shot dead by Israeli forces near Bethlehem.
The Israeli military said the teen, Mohammed Shehadeh, was throwing a Molotov cocktail before being shot by soldiers in the West Bank town of al-Khader.
Last Friday, a 12-year-old Palestinian boy was wounded by live Israeli fire during the weekly demonstration in the Nablus area in the West Bank.
4f81d6466fbbcaad3809d41264f9741f:
An Israeli man was killed in Ukraine on Monday while driving in a convoy heading toward the border with Moldova.
Israel has stationed representatives at border crossings with Poland, Hungary and Romania to help evacuate citizens and Jews.
About 4,000 Israeli citizens have left Ukraine but thousands more remain.
About 180,000 Jews are also eligible to immigrate to Israel based on the Law of Return.
Israel is planning to send three planes carrying 100 tonnes of humanitarian aid to Ukraine on Tuesday, including medical equipment, tents and coats.
07269e93385b74e2ece5fdaadb3632f3:
An Israeli Jew, Roman Brodsky, was shot and killed near Kyiv while attempting to leave the city and reach the border of Ukraine.
Israel's Foreign Ministry confirmed Brodsky's death and expressed condolences to his family.
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett offered condolences to Brodsky's family and stated that Israel is assisting Israelis in returning home.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy requested immediate full membership in the European Union.
The US has suspended embassy activities in Minsk, Belarus, and warned of consequences if Belarus continues to assist Russia.
Extensive bombings in Kharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, have killed dozens and injured hundreds.
Cease-fire talks between Russia and Ukraine have begun at the Belarusian border.
Zelenskyy addressed Russian soldiers, urging them to surrender and claiming that over 4,500 Russian soldiers have been killed.
Israel is preparing to send 100 tons of humanitarian aid to Ukraine, including water purification systems, emergency kits, and medical equipment.
Israel will cosponsor and vote in favor of a United Nations resolution condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Israel is considering imposing sanctions on Russia and has established an inter-ministry team to examine the potential impact.
58a6474ad674541ab94b4548e69dad91:
An Israeli citizen, Roman Brodsky, was shot dead in Ukraine by Ukrainian troops who mistook him for a Chechen militant.
Brodsky was part of a convoy of vehicles traveling to the Moldovan border to leave Ukraine.
Brodsky's family blames Russian President Vladimir Putin for his death.
Brodsky came to Israel at age 13 with his family and lived in the country for 27 years before returning to Ukraine about 2 years ago.
Prime Minister Naftali Bennett sent condolences to Brodsky's family and said Israel is doing everything to help Israelis return home.
The Foreign Ministry said it had informed Brodsky's wife and child who were still in Ukraine, as well as his parents in Israel.
As of Monday, 352 civilians have been killed and 1,684 people have been injured in the Russian offensive in Ukraine, according to the Ukrainian interior ministry.
Israel's Foreign Ministry estimated that several thousand Israeli citizens were still in Ukraine.
4bce9d53cb14561c83f5eb99159b5652:
Israel Defense Forces soldiers thwarted an attempt by Palestinian assailants to attack Israeli drivers near the West Bank town of Halhul on Monday night.
One suspect was hit by troops’ fire, and was arrested.
The other two suspects apparently fled the scene.
Israelis traveling along the area’s main traffic artery, Route 60, have repeatedly been attacked with Molotov cocktails and stones in recent weeks.
Two Palestinians were shot dead two weeks ago during confrontations with Israeli forces.
Israeli undercover police killed three other Palestinians during a rare daytime raid in the West Bank city of Nablus earlier this month.
88220349cd332282ece47ed49c8babfd:
A Palestinian man, Ammar Shafiq Abu Afifa, was shot dead by Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on Tuesday afternoon.
The Israel Defense Forces said soldiers operating security cameras identified two “suspects” approaching a lookout point near the settlement of Migdal Oz and opened fire toward them according to open-fire procedures.
The IDF did not detail what the two men were actually suspected of doing.
Also on Tuesday, a Palestinian who hurled a Molotov cocktail at troops was shot at in the northern West Bank.
Earlier Tuesday, security officials said a battle in the northern West Bank left two Palestinian gunmen dead.
The West Bank has seen a rise in violent confrontations between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians in recent weeks, leaving at least six Palestinians dead.
6173b4d6a67a8431f27331a80f35277a:
Two Palestinians, Shadi Najm and Abdullah al-Housri, were killed in a firefight with Israeli troops near the West Bank city of Jenin.
The suspect, Emad Abu al-Heija, is the son of imprisoned senior Hamas official Jamal Abu al-Heija.
Islamic Jihad terror group claimed al-Housri as a member and vowed revenge.
Masked gunmen affiliated with Islamic Jihad’s armed wing in Jenin published a menacing video after al-Housri’s death.
There were no casualties among Israeli forces, police said, and the suspect was arrested.
The West Bank has seen a rise in violent confrontations between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians in recent weeks.
Last week, a Palestinian teen was shot dead by Israeli troops while allegedly throwing Molotov cocktails at passing cars on Route 60 near Bethlehem.
A week before that a 19-year-old was shot and killed near Nebi Saleh after allegedly throwing firebombs at a military post.
Another Palestinian teen was killed that week during a firefight between Israeli soldiers and Palestinians in the town of Silat al-Harithiya, near Jenin.
Israeli undercover police killed three other Palestinians during a rare daytime raid in the West Bank city of Nablus last month.
15dddfde56ce04464b784cdd5af594d3:
A Palestinian was shot at after throwing a Molotov cocktail at troops in the northern West Bank.
Three Palestinians have been killed today in separate incidents.
Ammar Shafiq Abu Afifa, 21, was shot dead near the settlement of Migdal Oz under unclear circumstances.
Shadi al-Najm, 19, and Abdullah al-Housri, 22, were killed during a gunbattle near Jenin early this morning.
6bc987b3d270282f5b268595e29738be:
An Israeli citizen, Roman Brodsky, was killed by Ukrainian forces on Monday evening while trying to escape the country.
Another Israeli citizen, Yuri Shvidky, has been taken prisoner by the Russian navy while traveling on a Ukrainian cargo ship on the Black Sea.
Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett expressed condolences to Brodsky's family and stated that Israel is continuing to help Israelis return home.
Israel's Channel 12 News reported that Brodsky was shot at a Ukrainian checkpoint after security personnel mistook him for a Chechen militant fighting for Russia.
Shvidky's brother said that his brother had texted him that he was detained but had made no contact since then.
ff69a0ae8ac61832b3fa905903c5ada5:
U.S. Ambassador to Lebanon Dorothy Shea met with Prime Minister Najib Miqati and conveyed an official written communication from the U.S. Department of the Treasury.
The communication addresses concerns from Lebanese authorities regarding regional energy deals.
The letter ensures that the regional energy deals facilitated by the U.S. between Lebanon, Egypt, and Jordan will not violate U.S. sanctions legislation.
Lebanon launched two projects in the north to facilitate the flow of natural gas from Egypt to improve electricity production and expand oil reserves.
The Arab Gas Pipeline, out of service since before 2011, will be renovated by Egypt's Technical Gas Services within two months.
Egypt will supply Lebanon with natural gas through Jordan and Syria, despite U.S. sanctions on Syria.
U.S. officials have stated that the contract to bring gas from Egypt will not be targeted by sanctions as no cash is going to Syria.
About 650 million cubic meters of gas will be brought to Lebanon annually through the pipeline, leading to the production of 450 megawatts of electricity.
Lebanon signed a deal with Rosneft in 2019 to upgrade and operate storage installations in Tripoli.
Rosneft will rehabilitate and build tanks to increase strategic storage capacity to 400,000 cubic meters.
87ce01a37bf6a229b76064ebadbf3513:
The US State Department denied brokering an agreement for Israel to indirectly supply natural gas to Lebanon.
Channel 12 news reported that an agreement was signed in secret over the weekend, and will see Israel transfer gas from the offshore Leviathan field to Jordan, then to Syria and on to Lebanon.
The reported agreement was approved by the United States and was also coordinated with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The reported agreement is partly designed to provide Lebanon with an alternative to Iran, as it seeks to recover from a deepening economic crisis.
Lebanon is experiencing its worst-ever financial crisis, with a currency that has lost around 90 percent of its value, people’s savings trapped in banks, and qualified labor emigrating in droves.
Severe shortages in fuel have resulted in crippling power cuts and hours-long waits at gas stations.
The leader of Lebanon’s Hezbollah terror group, Hassan Nasrallah, announced in August that Iran was sending fuel to Lebanon to help ease the crisis.
Hezbollah has been taking part in Syria’s civil war alongside government forces and manages its own crossing points along the Lebanon-Syria border.
Lebanese Prime Minister Najib Mikati has said the Iranian fuel shipments violate Lebanon’s sovereignty and are not approved by his government.
Israel has said it will not interfere with the Iranian fuel shipments.
Energy ministers from Egypt, Jordan, Syria, and Lebanon in September agreed to a plan to bring Egyptian gas and Jordanian electricity to Lebanon via Syria.
b385578fe388bde7177b2fc4fb3c2aa3:
Lebanon's Energy Ministry dismissed an Israeli media report claiming that Israel has signed a US-mediated agreement to indirectly pump natural gas to Lebanon.
Lebanon's Energy Ministry stated that the natural gas will come exclusively from Egypt via Jordan and Syria.
The Israeli news report claimed that the gas deal was brokered by Amos Hochstein, Washington’s special envoy and coordinator for international energy affairs, and signed in secret over the weekend.
The London-based Rai al-Youm newspaper accused Israel of spreading "blatant lies" to sow discord and division in Lebanon.
The Syrian authorities cannot accept that the gas stolen by Israel be transferred from their soil to Lebanese territory.
In September last year, energy ministers from Jordan, Syria, Lebanon and Egypt agreed that Lebanon would import Egyptian gas and Jordanian electricity via Syria.
The United States supported the agreement, with US Ambassador to Beirut Dorothy Shea announcing that some of the Caesar Act sanctions against Syria could be amended to deal with the fuel transports.
Hezbollah imported Iranian fuel to help Lebanon weather serious fuel shortages in September last year.
Lebanon has been mired in a deep economic and financial crisis since late 2019.
50d3f77d6af2502f9094e348666a5657:
The U.S. State Department denied media reports that the United States has brokered an energy deal between Israel and Lebanon.
Israeli Channel 12 news reported that the U.S. had brokered an agreement for Israel to indirectly supply natural gas to Lebanon through Jordan and Syria, with the approval of the United States and Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The Lebanese Ministry of Energy affirmed that the natural gas is Egyptian, denying the media reports.
The natural gas from Egypt will be used to generate electrical power to the Lebanese who are currently living with only few hours of state electricity a day and are obliged to pay increasing hefty bills to private generator operators, which also depend on diesel fuel.
Internet services were disrupted in Lebanon on Sunday because of diesel shortages, which pushed head of state-run telecom provider OGERO, Imad Kreidieh, to threaten of resigning.
164b3bf64cd9c82e649335b3eff16bef:
Hezbollah has become a major political player in Lebanon by infiltrating key state institutions.
Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, has identified himself as a regional player with unabashed fealty to the agenda of Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.
Hezbollah's alliance with the Christian Free Patriotic Movement, led by President Michel Aoun, has proven to be unholy in all aspects.
The explosion that destroyed Beirut's port in August 2020 complicated things for Hezbollah.
Hezbollah and Amal have announced that their ministers are ending the Cabinet boycott for the sake of passing the 2022 budget and alleviating the economic crisis.
Hezbollah has become a burden on Lebanon's tired back.
A new deal must be struck that replaces the sectarian power-sharing system with an equitable arrangement that recognizes a single Lebanese national identity and that ends the two-decade hijack of the state by Hezbollah.
a6eb1c01f2704dcd16d04a498c0c9db7:
Saad al-Hariri, leading Lebanese Sunni Muslim politician, announced he would not run in the forthcoming parliamentary election and was suspending his role in political life.
Hariri called on his Future Movement not to run any candidates in the election.
Hariri has served as prime minister three times since inheriting the political mantle of his father, Rafik al-Hariri, after his assassination in 2005.
Hariri's announcement comes as Lebanon suffers an economic meltdown which the World Bank has described as one of the sharpest ever globally.
Hezbollah and its allies won a majority in the 2018 election, which adversaries hope to overturn in the vote scheduled for May.
Some analysts say a boycott by Lebanon's largest Sunni movement, which would leave the Sunni political scene in disarray, may lead to calls for a delay.
Hariri's last spell as prime minister ended in 2019 when he resigned in response to mass protests against the ruling elite.
787c06728b43c1297788b399fa82a83b:
Lebanon and Israel started indirect negotiations through U.S. mediation in 2020.
The negotiations took place at a UN peacekeeping base in Lebanon's Naqoura.
The talks have stalled.
d3421ce44fab82607e1207c8524ef1b8:
Lebanon is ready to resume talks over a maritime border dispute with Israel.
Lebanon and Israel have no diplomatic relations and are technically in a state of war.
Lebanon and Israel each claim about 860 square kilometers (330 square miles) of the Mediterranean Sea as being within their exclusive economic zones.
The two countries started indirect negotiations through a US mediator in 2020 at a UN peacekeeping base in Lebanon’s Naqoura, but the talks have stalled several times.
Lebanon has sunk deep into an economic and financial crisis that started in late 2019.
Lebanon is eager to resolve its border dispute with Israel, paving the way for potential lucrative oil and gas deals.
Israel’s Energy Ministry said in response that it is ready to resume talks.
US envoy Amos Hochstein will arrive in Israel next week to meet with Energy Minister Karine Elharrar and other officials.
Hochstein suggested to top Israeli officials during a visit to Israel that they need to get the deal done before the March 2022 parliamentary election in Lebanon.
Hochstein told officials that he was not planning to resume the joint talks held at a UN base on the border.
Hochstein was looking to get both sides to make serious compromises.
In October, the leader of Lebanon’s powerful Hezbollah terror group, Hassan Nasrallah, warned Israel against unilaterally searching for natural gas in the disputed maritime region before any agreement is reached.
d2ed4e37101a5b7fd19cc997daf5a6ec:
Lebanese President Michel Aoun declared that Lebanon was prepared to restart indirect negotiations with Israel over the two countries’ maritime borders.
Israel responded to the announcement by saying that “for us, the negotiations have never been stopped. But Lebanon must stop raising new demands.”
Aoun stressed that the drafting of these borders must be done “in a way that preserves Lebanon’s sovereignty.”
American mediator Amos Hochstein will meet in Israel next week with Energy Minister Karine Elharrar.
The United States is organizing the indirect talks.
Hochstein reportedly told both sides that he will give up on seeking a resolution to the dispute if a deal is not reached by the March parliamentary elections.
dbca208a158fa74118a80396381c614b:
US Vice President Kamala Harris visited Palawan, the closest Philippine landmass to the Spratly archipelago in the South China Sea, to show support for the Philippines and counter China’s growing influence in the region.
Harris met with fisherfolk and members of the Philippine Coast Guard, and in a speech, emphasized the importance of upholding "international rules and norms" and respecting the UN-backed tribunal decision rejecting China’s claims over the South China Sea.
Harris reaffirmed the United States’ “unwavering” commitment to defending the Philippines if its vessels or aircraft were attacked in the South China Sea.
Harris’s visit to Palawan comes a day after she held talks with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos in Manila, where she expressed support for accelerating the implementation of the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement (EDCA) between the US and the Philippines.
China has been pressing its stance most aggressively in the South China Sea, with hundreds of Chinese coast guard and maritime militia vessels patrolling the waters and harassing and attacking fishing and other boats.
On the eve of Harris’s visit to Palawan, a senior Philippine navy official accused the Chinese coast guard of “forcefully” seizing parts of a rocket that landed in the Spratlys.
Tensions between Manila and Beijing flared last year after hundreds of Chinese vessels were detected at Whitsun Reef in the Spratlys, and last November, Chinese coast guard ships fired water cannon at Philippine boats delivering supplies to marines at Second Thomas Shoal in the same archipelago.
cefdc645bf16093c92930fea15c4d057:
Three attacks against the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) were reported in one month, marking an unprecedented frequency.
UNIFIL has taken a firmer stance against the attacks, demanding accountability and a probe by Lebanese authorities.
UNIFIL's mandate under Resolution 1701 includes carrying out security measures in southern Lebanon and protecting its facilities and employees.
Lebanese academic Dr. Mona Fayad rejects accusations that "locals" are behind the attacks, instead holding Hezbollah responsible for mobilizing people under the guise of "resistance."
The attacks are seen as political messages from Hezbollah and Iran to the UN and international community, potentially tied to regional developments and Iran's setbacks.
Political researcher Khaled Hamade believes Iran is using Hezbollah to attack UNIFIL as a way to obstruct Resolution 1701 and exert pressure in the region.
Despite concerns, Hamade believes UNIFIL will remain in Lebanon as it serves the interests of Hezbollah, Iran, and Israel.
4164d7c227dffb1e2f8f5a9017ee6e5c:
Lebanon's government convenes for the first time in several months to negotiate a reform package with the International Monetary Fund to avoid economic collapse.
The Shiite duo of the Amal movement and Hezbollah ended their three-month boycott of cabinet sessions, allowing the government to convene.
The Lebanese Armed Forces (LAF) and Internal Security Forces (ISF) are experiencing challenges in carrying out their missions, which could create regional problems if Lebanon’s security and sovereignty are not protected.
The United States must act to help stabilize Lebanon, one of the few liberal democratic states in the Arab world.
Lebanon's collapse would end its many assets to the Middle East, including counterterrorism cooperation with the U.S., an inclusive democracy, religious coexistence, gender equality, and access to Western education.
Increased Iranian influence in Lebanon could lead to the country’s loss of sovereignty and independence and likely would result in a growing terror threat to the U.S.
The U.S. and its allies should promote the integrity of parliamentary elections on May 15.
The U.S. should join an international effort to provide election monitors and assistance to civil society organizations that promote democracy and clean government.
The U.S. should use its influence and leadership with countries such as France and the Gulf states to help combat corruption and promote reform in Lebanon.
The U.S. must continue to play a leadership role in the maritime border negotiations with Israel.
The U.S. must understand that any agreement it makes with Iran must impose a requirement for Iran to control — and eventually eliminate — its terrorist proxies in the Middle East, such as Hezbollah.
The Mikati government must quickly adopt a national budget and complete negotiations with the International Monetary Fund for an agreement that is fair to bank depositors, initiates banking and public sector reforms, and creates opportunities for businesses to grow and create employment.
f1c6fb52545c84ca7c73fe8d429feecd:
President Michel Aoun asked Foreign Minister Abdallah Bou Habib to file a U.N. Security Council complaint against Israel over its violation of Lebanon’s airspace to carry out an overnight strike on Syria.
Interior Minister Bassam al-Mawlawi briefed the Cabinet on the busting of “17 spy networks that were working for the Israeli enemy” inside Lebanon.
The Intelligence Branch of the Internal Security Forces detained around 20 people, including Lebanese, Palestinian and Syrian nationals, in the crackdown.
At least 12 of the suspects in detention were aware they working for Israel, while the rest believed they were providing information for global companies or non profit organizations.
Israel and Hizbullah fought a 33-day war in Lebanon in 2006.
Between April 2009 and 2014, Lebanese authorities detained more than 100 people accused of spying for Israel.
f66292c7450c90a58a5c3d2510649f93:
Lebanese President Michel Aoun has called upon the country’s top diplomat to file a complaint with the UN Security Council (UNSC) against the Israeli regime’s repeated violations of Lebanon’s sovereignty and airspace to carry out airstrikes in neighboring Syria.
Israeli warplanes fired several missiles from the direction of the eastern Lebanese town of Rayaq at some targets near Damascus at about 3:05 a.m. (0005 GMT) local time on Monday, but Syrian air defenses could bring down most of the projectiles.
Last month, the Lebanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Emigrants condemned in the strongest terms an Israeli missile strike against Syria’s strategic western port of Latakia.
Israel violates Lebanon's airspace and territorial waters on an almost daily basis, claiming the flights and incursions serve surveillance purposes.
Back on September 30 last year, fighters from Hezbollah intercepted and shot down an Israeli unmanned aerial vehicle while it was hovering over the southern part of Lebanon.
a5dd66bea186bd550a534893f599dfeb:
Lebanese President Michel Aoun called on Foreign Minister Abdallah Bou Habib to file a complaint against "Israeli violations" to the United Nations Security Council.
Syria's SANA news agency reported that Israeli fighter jets fired "several missiles" through Lebanese airspace at Damascus, and the Syrian air defences were able to "bring down most of the projectiles."
The Israeli warplanes "violated the Lebanese airspace from the Kafr Kila town to Dahr Al-Baydar", and the breaches were being "investigated in coordination with the UN Interim Forces in Lebanon (UNIFIL)."
Last month, the Lebanese foreign ministry condemned an Israeli missile strike against Syria's strategic western port of Latakia.
282b837909cdbb2fb8f6251d3852b353:
Defense Minister Benny Gantz said that Israel has offered the Lebanese army aid multiple times in the past year, including last week.
The offer was aimed to help the Lebanese army "face the strengthening of Hezbollah under Iran's support," Gantz said.
A senior Israeli official denied Gantz's claims, saying that Israel offered humanitarian aid to the people of Lebanon through the UN following an explosion in one of Lebanon's ports recently.
Gantz also said that the U.S. and Israel are promoting "operational cooperation" in face of a possible nuclear breakthrough by Tehran.
Gantz began a surprise visit to Bahrain on Wednesday, the first visit of an Israeli defense minister to Bahrain.
Prime Minister Naftali Bennett announced that Israel Defense Forces will start using a laser-based missile interception system 'within a year.'
2d1fd4faa576255d692cfc4faf6c0d97:
The U.S. has started to explore Hizbullah's position on the demarcation file between Lebanon and Israel.
The U.S. is examining Hizbullah's stance on the maritime borders demarcation, specifically regarding the common fields between Lebanon and Israel.
U.S. Special Envoy and Coordinator for International Energy Affairs Amos Hochstein will return to Lebanon mid-week carrying a new proposal.
Hochstein will suggest “stopping discussions over the above-the-water lines and focusing on splitting the resources based on the basins that are under the water.”
The shares of the two states can be split based on the sizes of these resources, away from the approach of direct lines.
This would be easy should it turn out that the basins of each of the two sides are closed, which would preserve their rights to their underwater resources.
9cde45bda009fec6bc1006630569a701:
Hizbullah deputy chief Sheikh Naim Qassem said that Hizbullah is not “worried” over the results of the upcoming parliamentary elections.
Qassem accused the U.S. Embassy in Lebanon of “sponsoring civil society organizations and building them on the basis of stirring chaos and troubles, sabotaging the country’s situation, blocking roads and spoiling the generations with perverse ideas and beliefs.”
Qassem said that the U.S. Embassy is endorsing the course of the Lebanese Forces, the party that committed massacres against the Lebanese throughout its entire history.
3ddfa1892f6620187febc5a5be1c1168:
Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah claims Israel is afraid to go to war against either Hezbollah or Iran.
Hezbollah will not immediately retaliate against Israel on Tehran’s behalf if Israel attacks Iran.
Hezbollah’s precision-guided missiles are spread all around Lebanon, so that Israel would need to launch a full-scale war in order to destroy them.
Hezbollah has unprecedented manpower, and Israel is afraid to go to war against it.
Israeli drone flights over Lebanon have stopped due to Hezbollah’s superior air defenses.
Hezbollah is against sharing offshore gas with Israel and doesn’t really care about negotiations between Beirut and Jerusalem over determining the countries’ exclusive economic zones.
41edb83c4f0a2b121e4b7360e4353372:
President Michel Aoun sent a letter to the U.N. about the sea border demarcation with Israel without consulting with Speaker Nabih Berri and Prime Minister Najib Miqati.

Parliamentary sources said Aoun addressed the letter in a “unilateral” manner without consulting with Berri and Miqati.
Foreign Minister Abdallah Bou Habib has cited Miqati’s “preoccupation with the draft state budget” as an “excuse” for not consulting with him.
Informed sources said that the visit of U.S. energy envoy Amon Hochstein to Lebanon is aimed at “splitting” the offshore oil and gas reserves between Lebanon and Israel instead of demarcating the maritime border.
aa83f0a142ba597157bb77b200ab0620:
U.S. Special Envoy and Coordinator for International Energy Affairs Amos Hochstein arrived in Lebanon Tuesday carrying a new proposal regarding the maritime borders demarcation between Lebanon and Israel.
Israeli Energy Minister Yuval Steinitz said that "Israel is ready to resume the maritime border talks with Lebanon."

The letter mentions a disputed area that includes a gas field, the Karish field that Lebanon is considering a disputed area.
Lebanon considers any Israeli attempt to explore gas in the area a threat to international peace and security.
